sp.p: 'Twill be but cold comfort, make the best on't; how am I transform'd? where's my low high German now? Duke of Ferrara quoth a':— wou'd I were any thing, I know not what I am, as they have handled me.

sp.speaker: Dutchess.
sp.p: Is the Duke gone?

sp.speaker: Courtier.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Dutchess.
sp.p: I'le have the fool hang'd then.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: That's I.

sp.speaker: Dutchess.
sp.p: Alas poor fellow, Ha, ha, ha, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Nothing, I hope she does not know me agen, I must deny my selfe.

sp.speaker: Dutchess.
sp.p: Come hither sirrah, whose devise was it to bid you say you were Duke of Ferrara?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Alas not I Madam, he is gone.

sp.speaker: Dutchess.
sp.p: Who is gone?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: The insolent fellow that made a fool of your Highness.

sp.speaker: Dutchess.
sp.p: Whether is he gone?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: To obey your Grace, and be whip'd.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: VVhy do you shake so?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I'm very warme and please your Grace.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: VVhere's your Clothiers.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: My Clothes? I never wore any more in my life, I sweat with these.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
Alas poor fellow,
he has punishment enough, who waites there.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Now to be sent to whipping cheer.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Bid Borgia attend us.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I shall Madam.

div.stage: Enter Borgia or Aurelio his Master.

sp.speaker: Borgia.
sp.p: How now sirrah, what are you?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: A tumbler; do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Borgia.
sp.p: I know thee?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: VVhat not Pimponio honest Pimponio.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Seignior Borgia her Grace calls for you.

sp.speaker: Borgia.
sp.p: I attend.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: How Seignior Borgia? then I am not I. And there is no staying here to find my selfe, as I remember some back friends of mine did promise a clean whipt, I'le rather endure the foulness of the weather then stay for't, I must be dukifi'd, be perswaded into Kicks— they'l return I won not tempt my desteny, she promis'd to hang me, and I can do that for my selfe when I have a mind to't.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtier.
sp.p: Kick that fellow out of the Court.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You are mistaken Sir, he meanes some body els, I have been kick'd already,

lg.l: Oh gentle fate rid me out of their clutches:
And then adue to our picked-dame Dutchess.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtier.
sp.p: What's the matter▪

div.stage: Pimponio within. Oh yes, Oh yes.

sp.speaker: Pisauro.
sp.p: A fool has lost his Master, and thus cryes him about the Court thy man Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh Yes;

lg.l: If any Man there be
In Town or in Countree
Can tell me of a wight,
Was lost but yester Night:
His name was I know
Seignior Aurelio,
Bring word to the Cryer
His desolate Squire,
By these marks, he is known
He had a bush of his own,
Two eyes in their place,
And a Nose on his face,
His Beard is very thin,
But no haire on his Chin,
And for this fine feat
Take what you can get;

sp.p: And heaven bless Pimponio, for no body knowes me and I know no body else to pray for.

sp.speaker: Pisauro.
sp.p: Here, here's thy Master.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: No, no, that's Seignior Borgia, not a word of whiping if you love me, do not deceive your selfe.

sp.speaker: Borgia.
sp.p: We have been both deceived, Pimponio I am thy master.

sp.speaker: Pimponio.
sp.p: Why then I'le wander through an other World with you, a World that hath more charity in't, then to uncase a man for doing his master Honour.

div.head: An Equall Match.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: A loose Officer, and a wanton waiting Woman, marry in hope of eithers Riches, and cozen one another.

sp.speaker: PErez.
sp.p: Shall I never return to my own house again? we are lodg'd here in the miserablest Doghole, a conjurers circle gives content above it, a Hawkes mew is a Princly pallace to't we have a bed no bigger then a basket, and there we lye like Butter clapt together, and sweat our selves to sauce immediatly, the fumes are infinite inhabit here too; and to that so thick they cut like Marmalet, so various too, they'l pose a Gold finder. Never return to mine own paradice? why wife I say, why Estifania?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: Within. I am coming presently.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Make hast good Jewell; I am like the people that live in the sweet Islands: I dye, I dye, if I stay but one day more here, my lungs are rotten with the damps that rise, and I cough nothing now but stinkes of all sorts; the Inhabitantes we have, are two starv'd Rats, for they are not able to maintaine a Cat here, and those appear as fearfull as two Divells, they have eat a map of the whole World up already, and if we stay a night longer we are gone for company, There's an old woman that's now grown to Marble, dry'd in this Brick hill, she sits 'ith Chimnies, which is but three tyles rais'd like a house of Cards, the true proportion of an old smok'd hovill, there is a young thing too, that's nature meant for a Maid servant, but 'tis now a monster, she has a huske about her like a Chesnut, with lasiness, and liveing under the line here, and these two make a hollow sound together, like Frogs or winds between two Doores that murmurs, mercy deliver me, O are you come wife! Shall we be free agen?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: I am now going, and you shall presently to your own house Sir, by that time you have said your Orisons, and broke your fast, I shall be back and ready to usher you to your old content, your freedome.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Break my neck rather, is there any thing here to eat but one another like a race of Canniballs, a peice of butter'd wall you think is excellent, let's have our house agen, immediatly, and pray ye take heed unto the Furniture, none be imbezelled?

sp.speaker: Estifania.
sp.p: Not a pin I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: And let 'em instantly depart.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: They shall both, for by this time she has acquainted him, and will give over gratefully unto you.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: I'le walk 'ith churchyard, the dead cannot offend me more then these living, an houre hence I'le expect you.

sp.speaker: Estifania.
sp.p: I'le not faile Sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p:
And do ye hear, lets have a handsome dinner, and let me have a strong
Bath to restore me, I stinke lik a stall-fish-shambles, or an Oyle-shop.

sp.speaker: Estifania.
sp.p: You shall have all; which some interpret nothing.

div.stage: Enter again Perez, with an old Woman and Maid.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Nay, pray ye come out, and let me understand ye, and tune your Pipe a little higher Lady, I'le hold ye fast:

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: Ha, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: My goods agen, how came my trunks all open.

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: Are your Trunks gone?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Yes, and clothes gone, and Chaines, and Jewells, how she smells like hung Beefe, the palsy and picklocks, fie how she belches the spirit of Garlick.

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: Where's your Gentlewoman? the young fair Woman?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: What's that to my question? she is my Wife, and gone about my business.

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: Is she your Wife Sir?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Yes Sir, Is that wonder, is the name of Wife unknown here.

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: Is she truely, truely your Wife?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: I think so, for I marryed her, it was no vision sure.

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: If you be marryed to that Gentlewoman you are a wretched man, she has twenty husbands.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: She tells you true.

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: And she has cozen'd all Sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: The divell she has, I had a fair house with her that stands hard by, and furnisht Royally.

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: You are couzen'd too, 'tis none of hers, good Gentleman, It is a Ladyes, what's the Ladyes name wench?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: The Lady Margarita, she was her servant, and kept the house, but going from her Sir, for some lewd tricks she plaid.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Plague a'the divell, Am I 'ith Meridian of my wisdome cheated by a stale Quean? what kind of Lady is that, that owes the house?

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: A young sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Of a low stature?

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: She is indeed of a low stature, but wondrous fair.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: I feel I am couzen'd, sensible I am undone, was she her Mistress say you?

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: Her own Mistress, her very Mistress Sir, and all you saw about that house was hers.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: No plate, no Jewells, nor no hangings? No Money?

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: She is a poor shifting thing, but for one Gown her Lady gave her.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: I am mad now, I think I am as poor as she, I am wild els, one civill suit I have left, and that's all, if she steal that she must flea me for it, where does she use?

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: You may find truth as soon, alas a thousand conceal'd corners Sir she lurkes in, and here she gets a fleese, and there another, and lives in mists and smokes where none can find her.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Is she a whore too?

sp.speaker: Old Wo.
sp.p: Little better Gentleman, I dare not say she is so, she is yours.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: A Whore and a Theife too, two excellent moral vertue, in one she's Saint, I hope to see her legend, well here's a Royall left yet, there's for your lodging and your meat for this weeke; a Silk-worme lives at a more plentyfull ordinary, and sleeps in a sweeter Box, Farewell great Grandmother, if I do find you were an accessary, 'tis but cuting off two smoaky minutes, I'le hang you presently.

div.stage: Enter again at one end, and his Wife at the other.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: 'Tis he, I am caught, I must stand to it stoutly.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: It is my evill Angell, let me bless me; my worthy wife?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: My most noble Husband.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: I have been in bawdy houses.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: I beleive you, and very lately too.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: To seek your Ladyship, in Cellers too, in private Cellers where the thirsty bawds heare your confessions, I was among the Nuns because you sing well, but they say yours are bawdy songs, they mourne for ye, and last I went to Church to seek you out, 'tis so long since you were there, they have forgot you.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: You have had a merry progress, I'le tell nine now, I went to twenty Taverns.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: And are you sober.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p:
Yes, I reel
not yet sir, where I saw twenty drunk, most of them Souldiers, from thence to'th Diceing-house, there I found quarrels needlesse, and sencelesse, Swords, and Pots, and Candlesticks, Tables, and Stooles, and all in one confusion; then to the Chyrurgions went, who learnedly told me, if you tippl'd hard twenty to one you whor'd too, and then he should hear of you; last to your Confessor I came who told me you were too proud to pray, and here I have found ye.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: She beares up bravely, and the Rogue is witty, why am I couzen'd, why am I abused? Thou most vile, base, abominable.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: Captain.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Thou stincking, overstew'd, poor, pocky.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: Captain.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: D'you eccho me.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: Yes sir, and go before you too, you had best now draw your Sword Captain, draw it, upon a VVoman, do brave Captain, upon your VVife, oh most renowned Captain.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: A plague upon thee, why didst thou marry me?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: To be my Husband.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Why didst thou flatter me, and shew me wonders, a House and riches? when they are but shaddowes, shaddowes to me.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: VVhy did you work on me with your strong Souldiers wit, and swore you would bring me so much in Chaines? so much in Jewels Husband, and here's your Treasure, sell it to a Tinker to mend old Nettles; is this noble usage?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: A Fire subtle you, are ye so crafty?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: Here's a goodly Jewel, did not you win this at Golletta Captain, or took it in the Field from some brave Bashaw? how it sparkles like an old Ladies eyes? and fils each Room with Light like a Dark-lanthorn, this would do rarely in an Abby Window, to couzen Pilgrims.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Prithe leave prating.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: And here's a Chain of Whitings-eyes for Pearles, a Mussel-monger would have made a better.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Nay, prithe VVife, my Cloathes, my Cloathes.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: I'le tell ye, your Cloathes are parallels to these all counterfeit, put these and them on, you are a Man of Copper, a kind of Candlestick, these you thought, my Husband to have couzen'd me withall, but I am quit with you.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: Is there no House then, nor no ground about it, no Plate, nor Hangings.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: There are none sweet Husband; shadow for shadow is an equall; justice, can you raile now? pray put your fury up sir, and speak great words, you are a Souldier, Thunder.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: I will speak little, I have plaid the fool, and so I am rewarded.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: You have spoken well sir.

div.head: The STALLION.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: A Gentleman falls into the hands of Officers, to whom be must either pay a summe of money, or be constrained to serve in the Gallies for some yeares, a Matrona to a Brothell, takeing a likeing to him, payes the imposed summe, and takes him to her House, where he serves the Womens unsatiate importunities; being dreyned and wearied, is by a happy accident released.

list.head: ACTORS NAMES.
list.item: three or four sick Persons belonging to the Brothell,

sp.speaker: BAud.
sp.p: Shall I never see a lusty Man again.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p:
Faith Mistress, you do so over-labour 'em, and so dry-founder
'em, they cannot last.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Where's the French-man?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Alas, he's all to fitters, and lies taking the height of his fortune with a Sirrenger, he's chin'd, he's chin'd good Man, he is a mourner.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: VVhat's become of the Don?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Who? gold Locks? he's foule i'th Touch-hole: and recoiles again, the main Springs weakned that holds up his Cock, he lies at the sign of the Sun to be new breech'd.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: The Rutter too is gon.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh, that was a brave Rascal, he would labour like a Thresher; but alas what thing can ever last? he has been ill-mew'd, and drawn too soon; I have seen him in the Hospital.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: There was an English-man.—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I, there was an English-man; you'l scant find any now to make that name good. There was those English-men, that were Men indeed, but they are vanisht: They are so taken up in their own Countrey, and so beaten off their speed by their own VVomen, when they come here they draw their Legges like Hackneys, drink, and their own devices have undone 'em.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: I must have one that's strong, no life in Lisbon else, perfect and young; my custome with young Ladies and high fed Citty-Dames will fall and break else, I want my selfe too in my age to nourish me; They are all sunck I maintain'd, now what's this business? what goodly fellows that?

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: VVhy do you drag me? Pox on your Justice, let me loose, cannot a Man fall into one of your drunken Cellars, and venture the breaking on's Neck, but he must be us'd thus rascally.

sp.speaker: 1 Officer.
sp.p: VVhat made you wandring so late i'th night? you know that is imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: May be I walk in my sleep.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: VVhat made you wandring sir, into that Vault where all the City store and the Ammunition lay?

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: I fell into't by chance, I broke my shins for't, your Worships feel not that; I knockt my Head against a hundred Posts, would you had had it, cannot I break my Neck in my own defence?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Your coming thither was to play the Villain, to fire the Powder and blow up that part o'th City.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Yes, with my Nose.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: We have told you what's the Law, he that is taken there, unlesse a Magistrate, and have command in that place, presently if there be nothing found apparent, neer him worthy his Torture, or his present death, must either pay his Fine for his presumption, (which is six hundred Duckets) or for six yeares tug at an Oake i'th Gallies; may be you were drunk, you'l be kept sober there.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Tug at an Oare, you are not errant Rascals to catch me in a Pit fall and betray me?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: A lusty-minded Man.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: O, wonderous able.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen allow me but that liberty to speak a few words with your Prisoner, and I shall thank you.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Take your pleasure Lady.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: What would you give that Woman should redeem you, redeem you from this slavery.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Besides my service, I would give her my whole selfe, I would be her Vassal.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: She has great reason to expect as much, considering the great summe she payes for't, yet take comfort, what you shall do to merit this, is easy, and I will be the Woman shall befriend you, 'Tis but to entertain some handsome Ladies, and young fair Gentlewomen; you guesse the way; but— giving of your mind—

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: I am excellent at it, you cannot pick out such another living; I understand you, is't not thus?▪—

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Ye have it.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p:
Bring me a hundred of 'em, I'le dispatch 'em, I will be none but yours; should another offer
another way to redeem me, I should scorn it, what Women you shall please; I am monstrous lusty, not to be taken down; would you have Children? I'le get you those as fast, and thick as fly-blowes.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: I admire him, wonder at him.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Hark you Lady, you may require some times.—

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: I by my faith.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: And you have it by my faith and handsomely; this old Cat will suck shrewdly; you have no Daughter? I fly at all; now I am in my Kingdom, Tug at an Oare? no, tug in a Feather-bed with good warm Caudles; hang your bred and water, I'le make you young again, beleeve that Lady; I will so frubbish you.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Come fellow Officers, this Gentleman is free; I'le pay the Duckets.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: And when you catch me in your Citty-powdering Tub again, boyle me with Cabbidge.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: You are borh warn'd and arm'd Sir.

div.stage: Enter Ruttillio with a Night-Cap, as in the Brothell-house.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p:
Now do I look as if I were Crow-trodden, fy, how my hams shrink under me; O me, I am broken-winded too; Is this a life? Is this the recreation I have aim'd at? I had a body once, a handsome body, and wholsome too; now I appear like a Rascal that had been hung a year or two in Gibbets, fy, how I faint; Women? keep me from Women; Place me before a Cannon, 'tis a pleasure; stretch me upon a Rack, a recreation; but VVomen? VVomen? O the Devill VVomen? courteous Gulfe was never halfe so dangerous; Is there no way to fall into the Cellar again, and be taken? no lucky fortune to direct me that way? no Gallies to be got, nor yet no Gallowes? for I feare nothing now, no Earthly thing but these unsatisfied Men-leeches, Women: how divelishly my bones ake: oh the old Lady! I have
a kind of waiting-VVoman lyes crosse my back too, oh how she stinks! no treason to deliver me? now what are you? do you mock me?

div.stage: Enter 3. or 4. with Night-caps very faintly.

sp.p: No sir no, we were your predecessors in this place.
And come to see how you beare up.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen, you seem to have a snuffing in your head sir, a parlous snuffing, but this same dampish ayre—
A dampish ayre indeed.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Blow your face tenderly, your nose will nere endure it; mercy on me, what are men chang'd to here? is my nose fast yet? methinks it shakes i'th hilts; pray tell me Gentlemen, how long is't since you flourisht here?
Not long since.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Move your selfe easily, I see you are tender, nor long endured.
The labour was so much sir, and so few to perform it—

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Must I come to this? and draw my legs after me like a lame dog? I cannot run away, I am too feeble; will you sue for this place again Gentlemen?
No truly sir, the place has been too warm for our Complexions.
VVe have enough on't, rest you merry sir, we came but to congratulate your fortune, you have abundance.
Beare your fortune soberly, and so we leave you to the next fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Stay but a little, and I'le meet you Gentlemen, at the next Hospital, there's no living thus, nor am I able to endure it longer, with all the helps and heates that can be given me, I am at my trot already; they are fair and young most of these VVomen that repair to me, but they stick on like burres, shake me like feathers, more VVomen yet?

VVould I were honestly married, to any thing that had but halfe a face, and not a great to keep her, nor a
smock, that I might be civilly merry when I pleased, rather then labouring in these fulling Mills.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: I see you bear up bravely yet.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Do ye hear Lady, do not make a Game-bear of me, to play me hourly, and fling on all your Whelps; it will not hold; play me with some discretion, to day one course, and two dayes hence another.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: If you be angry, pay back the money I redeem'd you at, and take your course; I can have Men enough: you have cost me an hundred Crownes since you came hither, in brothes and strengthning Caudles; till you do pay me, if you will eat and live, you shall endeavour, I'le chain you to't else.

sp.speaker: Ruttillio.
sp.p: Make me a Dog-kennel, I'le keep your House and bark, and feed on bare bones, and be whipt out a' doores, do ye mark me Lady? whipt, I'le eat old shooes.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Your businesse sir, if it be for a Woman, ye are cozen'd, I keep none here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Certain this is the Gentleman, the very same.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p: Death, if I had but money, or any friend to bring me from this bondage, I would thrash, set up a Coblers stall, keep Hogs, and feed with 'em, sell Tinder-boxes, and knights of Ginger-bread, that's for three halfe pence a day, and think it Lordly, from this base Stallion trade: why does he eye me, eye me so narrowly?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: It seemes you are troubled Sir, I heard you speake of want.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p: 'Tis better hearing far then relieving Sir:

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I do not think so, you know me not.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p: Not yet that I remember.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You shall, and for your friend, be confident I love you, by this you shall perceive it, 'tis Gold, & no small summe, a thousand duckets supply your want.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p: But do you do this faithfully.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: If I mean ill, spit in my face, and kick me; in what else I may serve you Sir, command.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p:
I thank you,
this is as strange to me as Knights adventure? where are you white broth? now lusty blood come in and tell your money: 'tis ready here, no threats, nor no Orations, nor prayers now.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: You do not meane to leave me.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p: I'le live in Hell sooner then here, and cooler, come quickly come, dispatch, this ayres unwholsome: quickly good Lady quickly to't.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Well since it must be, the next I'le fetter faster sure, and closer.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p: And pick his bones, as y'ave done mine, pox take ye.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: At my Lodging for a while, you shall be quarter'd, and there take Physick for your health.

sp.speaker: Rutt.
sp.p: I think I have found my good Angell now, if I can keep him.

div.head: The GRAVE-MAKERS.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: While▪ he is making the Grave, for a Lady that drown'd her selfe, Hamlet and his friend interrupt him with several Questions.

div.stage: Enter two to dig the Grave.
div.p: IS she to be buried in Christian burial, when she wilfully seekes her own Salvation?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I tell thee she is, therefore make her Grave streight; the Crowner hath sat on her, and findes it Christian burial.

sp.speaker: Grav.
sp.p: How can that be, unlesse she drown'd her selfe, in her▪ own defence?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why 'tis found so.

sp.speaker: Grav.
sp.p: It must be so offended, it cannot be else; for here lies the point, if I drown my self willingly it argues an act, and an act hath three branches, it is to act, to do, to perform, or all; she drown'd her selfe wittingly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, but hear you good man Delver.

sp.speaker: Grav.
sp.p: Give me leave, here lyes the water, good, here stands the man, good, if the man go to this water and drown himself, it is nill he, will he; he goes, mark you that: but if the water come to him and drowns him, he drowns not himself; argall, he that is not guilty of his own death, shortens not his own life.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But is this Law?

sp.speaker: Grav.
sp.p: I marry is't, Crowners quest law.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Will you have the truth on't, if this had not been a Gentlewoman, she should have been buried out a' Christian burial.

sp.speaker: Grave.
sp.p: Why there thou say'st, and the more pitty that great folke should have countenance in this World to drown or hang themselves, more then meaner christians: come my spade, there is no ancient Gentlemen but Gardeners, ditchers and Grave-makers, they hold up Adams profession.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Was he a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Grave.
sp.p: He was the first that ever bore Armes. I'le put another question to thee, if thou answer'st me not to the purpose, confesse thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Go to.

sp.speaker: Grave.
sp.p: What is he that builds stronger then either the Mason, the Ship-wright or the Carpenter?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: The Gallowes-maker, for that out-lives a thousand Tenants.

sp.speaker: Grave.
sp.p: I like thy wit well in good faith, the Gallowes does well, but how does it well? it does well to those that do ill, now thou dostill to say the Gallowes is built strongerthen the Church, Argall the Gallowes may do well to thee, to't again, come.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Who builds stronger then a Mason, a Ship-wright or a Carpenter?

sp.speaker: Grave.
sp.p: I, tell me that and unyoke.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Marry now I can tell.

sp.speaker: Grave.
sp.p: To't.

sp.speaker: Man▪
sp.p: Mass I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Grave.
sp.p: Cudgell thy braines no more about it, for your dull Ass will not mend his pace with beating, and when you are askt this question next, say a Grave-maker, the houses he makes last till Doomesday, go get thee in and fetch me a soope of Liquor.

lg.l: In youth when I did love, did love
Methought it was very sweet,
To contract, O the time for a my behove,
O methought there was nothing a meet.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Has this fellow no feeling of his business? a sings in Grave-making.

lg.l: But age with his stealing steps
Hath clawed me in his clutch,
And hath shiped me into the Land,
As if I had never been such.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: That skull had a tongue in it, & could sing once, how the knave jowles it to the ground, as if 'twere Caines Jaw-bone, that did the first murder: this might be the pate of a pollitician which this Ass now o're-reaches, one that would circumvent God, might it not?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: It might Sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Or of a Courtier, which could say, good morrow my Lord, how dost thou sweet Lord? this might be my Lord such a one, that praised my Lord such a ones Horse when he meant to beg it, might it not?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Hamlet.
sp.p: Why ee'n so, and now my Lady Wormes choples, and knocks about the mazer with a Sextons spade, here's fine revolution, and we had the trick to see't, did these bones cost no more the breeding but to play at loggits with 'em? mine ake to think on't.

lg.l: A Pickaxe and a Spade a spade,
For and a shrowding sheet,
O a pit of Clay for to be made
For such a Guest is meet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: There's another, why may not that be the Scull of a Lawyer? where be his quiddities now? his quillities, his cases, his termes, and his tricks? why does he suffer this mad knave now to knock him about the sconce with a durty shovell, and will not tell him of his actions of battery? hum: this fellow might be in's time a great buyer of Land, with his statutes, his rogguizance, his fines, his double vouchers, his recoveries, to have his fine pate full of fine durt; will vouchers vouch him no more of his purchases and doubles, then the length and bredth of a paire of Indentures? the very conveyances of his land will scarcely lye in this Box, and must the Inheritor himselfe have no more? Ha?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Not a jot more Sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Is not parchment made of Sheep skins?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I Sir, and of Calves skins too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: They are Sheep and Calves which seek out assurance in that. I will speak to this fellow: whose Grave's this firrah?

sp.speaker: Gravemaker.
sp.p: Mine Sir, or a pit of Clay for to be made.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I think it's thine indeed, for thou ly'st in't.

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: You lye out on't Sir, and therefore 'tis not yours: for my part I do not lye in't, yet it is mine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Thou dost lye in't, to be in't and say it is thine, 'tis for the dead, not for the quick, therefore thou ly'st.

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p:
'Tis a quick lye Sir, 'twill again from me to
you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What man dost thou dig it for?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: For no man Sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What Woman then?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: For none neither.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Who is to be bury'd in't?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: One that was a VVoman Sir, but rest her soul, she's dead.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How long hast thou been a Grave-maker.

sp.speaker: Gravem,
sp.p: Of the dayes 'ith year I came to't, that day that our last King Hamlet overcame Fortinbrass.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How long is that since?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: Cannot you tell that? every fool can tell that; it was that very day that young Hamlet was born, he that is mad, and sent into England.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I marry, why was he sent into England?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: Why, because he was mad, a shall recover his wits there, or if he do not, 'tis no great matter there.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: 'T will not been seen in him there, there are Men as mad as he.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How came he mad?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: Very strangly they say.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How strangely?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: Faith ee'n with loosing his wits.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Upon what ground?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: Why here in Denmarke: I have been Sexton here man and boy thirty yeares.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How long will a man lye 'ith earth e're he rot?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: Faith if he be not rotten before he dye, as we have many pocky courses that will scarce hold the laying in, a will last you some eight year or nine year; a Tanner will last you nine year.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why he more then another?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p:
Why Sir his Hide is so tan'd with his Trade, that a will keep out water a great while, and your water
is a sore decayer of your whorson dead body: here's a scull now hath layn you 'ith earth twenty three yeares.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: A whorson mad fellow it was, whose do ye think it was?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay I know not.

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: A pestlence on him for a mad Rogue, a powr'd a Flaggon of Rhenish on my head once; this same scull Sir, was Sir Yoricks the Kings Jester.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: This?

sp.speaker: Gravem.
sp.p: ‛ Een that.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Alas poor Yorick, I knew him friend, a fellow of infinite jest, of most excellent fancy, but where be your Gibes now▪ your Gamboles, your Songs of merryment? quite chop fal'n? prithee friend tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What's that Sir?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Dost thou think Alexander lookt a this fashion 'ith earth?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: ‛ Een so.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And smelt so? pah.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ee'n so Sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: To what base uses may we return? why may not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander, till a find it stopping a Bung-hole.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Twere to consider, too curiously to consider so.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: No faith not a jot, but to follow him thither with modesty enough, and likelihood to lead it: Alexander dyed, Alexander was buryed, Alexander returned to dust, the dust is Earth, of Earth we make Lome, and why of that Lome whereto he was converted, might they not stop a Beer-barrel?

lg.l: Imperial Caesar dead, and turn'd to clay,
Might stop a hole to keep the wind away;
Oh that that Earth which kept the World in awe,
Should patch a Wall t'expell the Water flaw.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Who rescue their Prince condemn'd to dye, by the plots and designes of his Step-Mother.

sp.speaker: CItizen.
sp.p: Sirrah, go fetch my Fox from the Cutlers; there's money for the scowring, tell him, I stop a groat since the last great Muster he had in store pitch for the bruise he took with the recoyling of his Gun.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: And do you hear? when you come, take down my Buckler, and sweep the Cobwebs off, and grind the Pick on't, and fetch a Nayle or too, and tack on the Bracers; your Mistresse made a Potlet on't, I thank her, at her Maids wedding, and burnt off the handle.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: Whose within here, ho, neighbour, not stirring yet?

sp.speaker: 2 Citizen.
sp.p: Oh good morrow, good morrow: what newes, what newes?

sp.speaker: 1 Citiz.
sp.p: It holds, he dyes this morning.

sp.speaker: 2 Citiz.
sp.p: Then happy Man be his fortune; I am resolv'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Citiz.
sp.p: And so am I, and forty more good fellows, that will not give their heads for the washing, I take it.

sp.speaker: 2 Citiz.
sp.p: 'Sfoot Man, who would not hang in such good Company? and such a Cause? A fire, a Wife, and Children, 'tis such a jest that Men should look behind 'em to the World; and let their honours, their honours neighbourship.—

sp.speaker: 1 Citiz.
sp.p: I'le give thee a pint of Bastard, and a Role for that bare word.

sp.speaker: 2 Citiz.
sp.p: They say that we Taylors are things that lay one another, and our Geese hatch us; I'le make some of 'em feele they are Geese 'oth Game then, Iack take down my Bill, 'tis ten to one I use it; take a good heart Man, all the low Ward is ours with a wet finger: and lay my cut-fingred Ganlet ready for me, that, that I used to work in when the Gentlemen were up against us, and beaten out of Town, and almost out of debt too; for a plague on 'em, they never paid well since: and take heed sirrah, your Mistress heares not of this businesse, she's neer her time; yet if she do, I care not, she may long for Rebellion, for she has a devilish spirit.

sp.speaker: 1 Citiz.
sp.p: Come lets call up the new Ironmunger, he's as tough as steele, and has a fine wit in these resurrections, are you stiring Neighbour.

sp.speaker: 3 Citizen within.
sp.p: Oh good morrow
Neighbours, I'le come to you presently.

sp.speaker: 2 Citiz.
sp.p: Go to, this is his Mothers doing; she's a Ponlcat.

sp.speaker: 1 Citiz.
sp.p: As any is in the VVorld.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Then say I have hit it, and a vengeance on her Let he●… be what she will.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: Amen say I, she has brought things to a fine pass with her wisdome: do you marke it?

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: One thing I am sure she has, the good old Duke she gives him Pap again they say, and dandles him, and hangs a Currall and Bells about his Neck, and makes him beleive his teeth will come again, which if they did, and I he, I would weary her as never Cur was wearyed: I would Neighbour, till my teeth meet, I know where— but that's councell.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: Good morrow neighbours: hear you the sad news?

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p:
Yes, would we knew aswell how
to prevent it.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: I cannot tell, methinks 'twere no great matter, if men were men: But.—

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: You do not twit me with my calling neighbour?

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: No surely: for I know your spirit to be tall, pray be not vext.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Pray forward with your councell: I am what I am: And they that prove me, shall find me to their cost: do you marke me neighbour? to their cost I say.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: Nay look how soon you are angry.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: They shall neighbour: Yes, I say they shall.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: I do believe they shall.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: I know they shall.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Whether you do or no, I care not two pence, I am no beast, I know mine own strength Neighbours; God bless the King, your companyes is fair.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: Nay now you erre, Neighbour I must tell you so, were ye twenty neighbours.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: You had best go Peach, do peach.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Peach, I scorn the motion.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: Do and see what followes: I'le spend an hundred pounds, and it be two I care not, but I'le undo thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Peach, Oh disgrace! Peach in thy face, and do the worst thou canst I am a true man, and a free man, peach.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: Nay, look, you will spoile all.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Peach.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: Whil'st you two brawle together, the Prince will loose his life.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz
sp.p: Come give me your Hand, I love you well, are you for the action?

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Yes, but Peach provokes me, 'tis a cold fruit, I feel it cold in my stomack still.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: No more, I'le give you Cake to digest it.

sp.speaker: 4. Citiz.
sp.p:
Shut up my Shop, and be ready at a call boys, and one of you run over my old Tuck with a few ashes, 'tis grown odious with tosting Cheese! and burn a little Gun-powder in my murrin, the maid made it her chamber
pot, an hour hence I'le come again; and as you hear from me, send me a clean Shirt.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: The chandler by the Wharfe, and it be thy will.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Gossip, good morrow.

sp.speaker: 4. Citiz.
sp.p: O good morrow Gossip: good morrow all, I see you of one mind ye cleave so close together: Come 'tis time, I have prepared a hundred if they stand.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: 'Tis well done: shall we sever, and about it?

sp.speaker: 4. Citiz.
sp.p: If my Tuck hold, I'le spit the Guard like Larkes with Sage in th'be●…y o'um.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: I have a foolish Bill to reckon with 'um, will make some of their hearts ake, and I'le lay it on: now shall I fight, 'twill do ye good to see me.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: Come I'le do something for the Town to talk of when I am rotten: pray God there be enough to kill, that's all.

div.head: Invissible Smirk, or the Pen Combatants.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: A day of Iuble is appointed by the Duke, wherein every one to expresse his duty endeavours something of Mirth, to Crown that day.

sp.speaker: SMIRK.
sp.p:
Thanks my dear Jem, I've found thy vertue now, I had not past 'em els, a man may have an invissible Ring I see and not know of it, what is this all the
divices sports and delights the Duke shall have for his money? the Proclamation promiseth reward for him, shall shew any varieties, and will it all come to a dull Masque? I'le shew his Grace some sport my selfe with help of my good friend here, which now must off again, by your Majesties leave.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How now what's he?

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: What's he? the wonder of your Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How, the wonder▪

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I, and can do the greatest,— now you see me you know me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I do know you.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: And you all see me, you say.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: And I do see all you, but what's that to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Very little I confess.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Shall I demonstrate matter of Art, and have nothing for my paines.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No, no, the Proclamation speaks the contrary.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Well, because Royalty shall have no wrong in suspecting your Bounty— you see me you say.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes, we do.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: But who sees me now?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Trust me he's invissible to me.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: And to us all.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I should be very sorry els; for, and my invissible Ring should not keep his old vertue, I would hang my selfe directly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Prithee appear again.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I will have Majesty call me first.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why, the Duke does call you.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Let me hear him Viva Voce, Smirk is my name, a welbeloved Subject, once a Painter, but now Squire of the invissible Ring.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Smirk, and our welbeloved Subject, once a Painter, but now Esquire of the invissible Ring I conjure thee to appear again.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: See here I am, what wilt thou mighty Monarch?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I do command thee let me see the Ring by which thou walk'st invissible.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I do command thee not to command me that, for from my invissible Ring I will not part.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lay hands upon him for a Sorcerer.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Assist me my dear Ring, no hands upon me, for being invissible I am a Prince, no hands is to be laid on me, Treason doth never prosper.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Nay, then, what hoh.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.p: Thy will?

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Seize it, and fly.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How? whose that exclaimes?

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: The cramps in my Finger.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: The cramp?

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I the Cramp; the Ring that cur'd it is gone, the divell go with it, for on my conscience he fetcht it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What's become of the Ring?

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Pardone me my leige, the vertue that it held came from my Art, the Dutchess found the worth on't when time was.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thy knowledge in good Arts is warranted by us, since all thy actions have been just and loyal—- what meanes this.

lg.l: Thus was I bidden to my Soveraign,
Fall on my face, now rise I up again,
To render to the Ladyes fair salutes,
And give them all their worthy Attributes,
Wonder not that I resolutly come
Boldly, thus daring press into this roome,
For from a Lord'tis said of eminent note,
I bring this challenge such as can read may know't.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Very succinct and peremptory.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What i'st?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A Challenge.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Read it.

sp.speaker: Conju.
sp.p: For this day I am Master of the Revels.

Be it known unto all Men that I, Visconnt Shallew doth Challenge all Courtiers whatsoever at the true compendious forme of compiling Epistles, Alias love letters to Ladyes, or Mistresses▪ either in prose or verse ex tempore or not, ex tempore according as it shall please the challenged

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Here's unexped sport, Smirk thou shalt take him up, I'le wager on thy side.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Say you so Sir, shall I be the man, 'twill recompence my loss of the Ring for I know I shall beat him out o'th Pit with Oratry and Poetry.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: Which is my Antagonist?

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Behold the Man with Pen and Inke provided.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: Poor fool thou wilt but make thy self derided.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: So nimble in rime, I'le first break your neck in prose, and afterwards whip you in verse, I'le I ambast you in couplets: you challenge all men to compose.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: With figures or without figures, with sentences or without sentences.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: 'Tis right.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Draw out your pen and Inkhorn I am for you.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: With expedition too, I put in that.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: No, expedition belongs to Clerkes, and not to Secretaries.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: I Sir, celerity I mean.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: No more but so, a word's enough.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Smirk goes on smoothly without any rub.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Yet there he had one.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Hold byas, and a sentence then.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: Scripsi.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Et Scripsi.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Now lordings lend your Eares.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: I will read it first my selfe.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Good reason

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: Fairest in the World, and sweetest upon earth.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: So so, so.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: I remember my duty to you in black and white.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I would it had been black and blew.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: For all colours else, wave under the standard of your beauty; you are the Mistress of beauty, all other Women are but your hand-maids.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Oh abominable barren.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Nay, Smirk silence, you must not interrupt your adversary.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: I can say nothing, without saying too much, nor say too much without saying nothing.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I can say nothing, or els I wou'd say something, but here it is shall shame thee and thy Lordly botching.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: Methinks when thou standest in the Sun with thy feather on thy head, and thy Fan in thy hand, thou look'st like the Phenix of the East Indies, burning in spices, for Cloves, Mace, and Nutmegs are in thy breath.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: She would make an excellent Wassell boale.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Again, fy, fy.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I have done.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: The apples of thy breast are like the Lemons of Arabia which makes the Vessel so sweet, it can never smell of the Caske.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If she should, it might prove the Brewers fault.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: Being come to your midle I must draw to an end, for my end is at the midle, because of the Proverb, In Medio consistit vertus, and so I conclude: yours while mine own, and afterwards if it were possible.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: VVell, now let me run on, judgment I crave.—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Which thou shalt have.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p:
Illustrious, bright shining, wellspoken, an●… blood
stirring Lady.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I marry Sir.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: If the Rope of my capacity could reach to the Belfry of your beauty, these words of mine like Silver Bells might be worthy to hang in the ears of your favour; but the Ladder of my invention is too low to climb up to the Steeple of your understanding.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Excellent Smirk.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: If it were not, I should ring out my mind to you in a sweet Peal of most savory conceits. For your face it is like the Sun, no man is able to endure it.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Your forehead which I will neither compare to Alleblaster nor to the Lilly, but it is, as it is, and so are both your Eyes; for your Nose, it is a well arched bridge, which for brevity sake I passe over: Your cheeks are like a good Comedy, worthy to be clapt: your lips and your teeth are incomparable; your tongue like the Instrument of Orpheus, able to tame the furies: to handle e'ry part of you were too much, but some particular part, no man can sufficient.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Prithee let me give thee a box on the Eare, for that conceit.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: No my good Lord, pray keep your bounties; From top to toe you are a sweet Vessel of delight, I dare not say a Barrel, for often times with much joulting the Brewer beates out the bunghole, and so the good liquor runs out, but you containe yours although not hoopt about with the old farthingall after the newest fashion, and so I leave you fairest of a hundred, and wittyest of a thousand, resting in little rest till I rest wholly yours in the Down bed of affection, where ever standing to my utmost I rest all in all yours.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Could any man have said more?

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p:
Spare your censures a while Gentlemen; now Sir I challenge you in verse, in praise of tall Women, and
little Women, choose your subject, which you refuse I'le take.

sp.speaker: Smirk
sp.p: Why then I'le take your little Women.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: And I your lusty, proceed.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Some patience will be required from us, for their verse cannot come off so roundly as their prose.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: As roundly as a Runlet of Sake Sir, I'le warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: Scripsi.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Sed non feci, stay a little here are a couple of lines, a Halter on 'em, they won not twist hansomely, go forward I have ended.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Attention.

lg.l: Listen you tall, and likewise you low man,
I sing the praises of a bouncing Woman:
A full, well set, big-bon'd, and fairly jointed.
Fit to bid welcome, Men, are best appointed.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Excellent.

lg.l: To your tall Women, your little one is nothing,
No more then is a high thing, to a low-thing.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: That's true.

lg.l: For your small dandiprat, I hope there's no man,
That thinks her but a hobby-horse to Woman,
A thing to be forgot, and never known,
But on a holy day, to the rout shewn,
In Wars the Basilisco is prefer'd,
Before the Musket, and is louder hear'd.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: There's an Error, little, and loud (my friend.)

lg.l: In every Tryumph where there is excesse,
The greater alwayes puteth down the less.
The Lyoness is more admired at,
Then her Epitome, which is a Cat.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: The fool growes serious: He hath stollen it certainly.

lg.l: But to weak understandings now I come,
Is your small Taber musick to your Drum?

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p:
Hum, drum, he has hit within an Inch of a conceit
of mine.

lg.l: Or in an Instrument of peace, can there that cryal
Be made upon a Kit, as a base Violl?
Judge you my Masters, that on both have plaid,
It is but my opinion, and I've said.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Come thou hast said well, Smirk look to your selfe.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I warrant you, give me Audience.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Silence.

lg.l: In praise of little Women I begin,
And will maintain what I have enter'd in:
Is not your Parochit, or Marmoset,
In more request then your Baboone or Parret?
Give but your little wench freely her Liquor,
And to bed send her, you will find her quicker;
Pearter, nimbler, both to kiss, and cog,
Then your great wench that will lye like a Log:
And he that all day at the Drum doth labour,
Would at night gladly play upon a Taber.
I hope there's no man but of this beliefe,
That Veal's more sweet and nourishing then Beefe:
Small meates are still prefer'd, for ask your Glutton,
He'l always say Lambs sweeter then your Mutton,
Your Smelt then whiting firmer is, and sounder,
Nor must your Place compare with your neat Flounder.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well said, now thou art in good victualls thou'lt never out.

lg.l: In fish or flesh I'le prove it to each wight
A Larkes leg, then the body of a Kite
Is better far; Our Bakers alwayes make
The finest flour in the lesser Cake,
And I'le be judg'd by those that rootes do eat,
That your small Turnip's better then your great.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: I am of thy mind too.

lg.l: Who list to be resolv'd, let 'um both try,
In that beleife I live, in that I'le die

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Incomparable Smirk, thou'st my voice, judgment.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A Smirk, a Smirk.

div.head: The three Merry Boyes.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: The King a Tyrant, employes them to kill his Elder Brother, the Pantler betrayes it, but the business being done, they all suffer, &c.

div.stage: Enter the Master Cooke, Butler, Pantler, Yeomen of the Cellar with a Iack of Beere, &c.

sp.speaker: COok.
sp.p: A hot day, a hot day, vengeance hot day boyes, give me some drink, this fire's a plaguy fretter: body of me I am dry still, give me the Jack boy, this wooden skiff holds nothing.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: And faith Master, what brave new meates? for here will be old eating.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Old and young boy; let 'em all eat, I have it; I have ballasse for their bellies, if they eat a Gods name, let them have ten tire of teeth a peece, I care not.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: But what new rare munition.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p:
Pish, a thousand; I'le make your Pigges speak French at Table, and a fat Swan come sailing out of England with a Challenge; I'le make you a Dish of Calves-feet dance the Canaries, and a consort of cram'd Capons fidle to 'em; a Calves-head speak an Oracle, and a douzen of Larkes rise from the Dish and ●…ing all super time; 'tis nothing boyes: I have framed a fortification out of Rie past which is impregnable, and against that, for two long hours together, two douzen of Marrow-bones shall play continually; for fish, I'le make you a standing lake of white broth, and Pikes come ploughing up the plums before
them; Arion like a Dolphin, playing lachrymo, and brave King Herring with his Oyle and Onyon crown'd with a Lemon pill, his way prepar'd with his strong Guard of Pilchers.

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: I marry Master.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: All these are nothing: I'le make you a stuble Goose turn o'th toe thrice, do a cross point presently, and sit down agen, and cry come eat me: These are for mirth: now Sir, for matter of mourning, I'le bring you in the Lady loyne of Veal, with the long love she bore the Prince of Orange.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Thou Boy, thou.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: I have a trick for thee too, and a rare trick, and I have done it for thee.

sp.speaker: Yeoman.
sp.p: What's that good Master?

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: 'Tis a Sacrifice: a full Vine bending like an Arch, and under the blown God Bacchus, sitting on a Hogshead, his Alter-beer: before that plump Vintner kneeling and offering incense to his deity, which shall be only red sprats and pilchers.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: This when the Tables drawn, to draw the Wine in.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Thou hast it right, and then comes thy song Butler.

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: This will be admirable.

sp.speaker: Yeom.
sp.p: Oh Sir most admirable.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: If you'l have the Pasty speak, 'tis in my power, I have fire enough to work it; what friends hast thou to day? no Citizens?

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: Yes father, the old crew.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: By the Masse true Wenches: sirrah set by a Chine of Beefe, and a hot Pasty, and let the Joll of sturgeon be corrected: and do you marke Sir, stalke me to a Pheasant, and see if you can shout her in the Celler.

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: God a mercy lad, send me thy roaring bottles, and with such Nectar I will see 'em fill'd that all thou speak'st shall be pure helicon.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: But what was't we did promise to Monsiure Latorch.

sp.speaker: Yeoman.
sp.p: Do you ask that now?

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: I'le tell you It is to be all villaines, knaves and Traytors.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Fine wholsome titles.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: But if you dare go forward.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: May be hang'd drawn and quarter'd.

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: Very true Si●….

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: What a goodly swing I shall give the Gallowes? yet I think too, this may be done, and yet we may be rewarded, not with a Rope, but wit●… a Royal Master: and yet we may be hang'd too.

sp.speaker: Yeoman.
sp.p: Say it were done; who is't done for? is it not for alio? and fo●… his right?

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: And yet we may be hang'd too?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Or say he take it, say we be discover'd? Is not the same mam found to protect us? are we not his?

sp.speaker: Yeom.
sp.p: Sure he will never fail us.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: If he do, friends, we shall find that will hold us; & yet methinks, this Prologue to our purpose, the Crowns were given, should promise more: 'Tis easily done, as easy as a man would roast an Egge, if that be all; for look you, Gentlemen, here stand my brothes, my finger slips a little, down drops a Dosse, I stir him with my Ladle, and there's a Dish for a Duke: Olla podrida, here stands a Bak'd meat, he wants a little seasoning, a foolish mistake; my Spice-box, Gentlemen, and put in some of this, the matter's ended; dredge you a dish of Plovers, there's the a●…t on't.

sp.speaker: Yeoman.
sp.p: Or as I fill my Wine.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: 'Tis very true Sir, blessing it with your hand, thus quick and neatly first, when 'tis past and done once, 'tis as easy for him to thank us for it, and reward us.

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: But 'tis a damn'd sin.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Oh never feare that, the fire's my playfellow, and now I am resolv'd boyes.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Why then have with you.

sp.speaker: Yeoman.
sp.p: The same for me.

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: For me too.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: And now no more our worships, but our Lordships.

sp.speaker: Pantl.
sp.p: Not this year on my knowledg, I'le un-Lord you.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Make roome before there, roome for the Prisoners.

sp.speaker: 1▪ Boy.
sp.p: Are these the Youths?

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p:
These are the Youths you look for, and pray my honest friends
be not too hasty, there will be nothing done till we come I assure you.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: Here's a wise hanging, are there no more?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Do you hear, you may come in for your share, if you please.

sp.speaker: 3. Boy.
sp.p: Afore, afore, Boyes here's enough to make us sport.

sp.speaker: Yeoman.
sp.p: Pox take you, do you call this sport? are these your recreations? must we be hang'd to make you mirth.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Do you hear Sir? you custard pate, we go to't, for high treason, an Honourable fault: thy foolish father was hang'd for stealing sheep.

sp.speaker: ●…. Boy.
sp.p: Away Boyes, away.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Do you see how that sneaking Rogue looks now? you, chip, Pantler, peaching Rogue, that provided us these Neck-laces: you poor Rogue, you costive Rogue you.

sp.speaker: Pantler.
sp.p: Pray, pray, fellowes.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Pray for thy crusty Soul? where's your reward now goodman manchet for your fine discovery? I do beseech you Sir, where are your dollers? draw with your fellowes and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Yeoman.
sp.p: You must now, for now he shall be hang'd first, that's his comfort, a place too good for thee thou meal-mouth'd Rascall.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Hang hansomely, for shame come leave your praying, you peaking knave, and be like a good Courtier; die daringly, and like a man; no preaching, with I beseech you take example by me, I liv'd a lewd man, good people; pox on't: die me as if thou had'st din'd, say grace, and Heaven be with you.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Come will you forward?

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Good Mr. Sheriffe, your leave to, this hasty work was ne're done well, give us so much time as but to Sing our own ballads for wee'l trust no man, nor no time but our own, 'twas done in Ale too, your penny pot Poets, are such pelting theeves, they ever hang men twice, we have it here Sir, and so must every Merchant of our Voyage, he'l make a sweet return else of his Credit.

sp.speaker: Yeo.
sp.p: One fit of our mirth, and then we are for you.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Make hast then, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Yeo.
sp.p: There's day enough Sir.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Come Boyes, sing cheerfully, we shall ne're sing younger; we have chosen a lewd tune too, because it should like well.

lg.l: Come, fortune's a Whore I, care not who tells her,
Would offer to strangle a Page of the Celler,
That should by his Oath, to any mans thinking,
And place, have had a defence for his drinking;
But thus she does still, when she pleases to palter
Instead of his wages, she gives him a Halter.
Three merry boys & three merry boys & three merry boys are we
As ever did sing in a bempen string, under the Gallow Tree.
But I that was so lusty,
And ever kept my Bottles,
That neither they were musty,
And seldome less then Pottles;
For me to be thus stopt now,
With 'hem instead of Corke Sir,
And from the Gallowes topt now,
Shews that there is a Forke Sir,
In death, and this the token
Man may be two wayes killed,
Or like the Bottle broken,
Or like the Wine, be spilled.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.p: And three merry Boyes, &c.

lg.l: Oh yet but look on the Master Cooke, the glory of the Kitchin,
In sowing whose fate, at so loftly a rate, no Taylor e're had stitching,
For though he makes the man, the Cooke he makes the Dishes;
The which no Taylor can, wherein I have my wishes,
That I who at so many a feast have pleas'd so many tasters
Should now my selfe come to be drest a dish for you my Masters.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.p: And three merry Boyes, &c.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: There's a few copies for you; now farewell friends: and good Mr. Sheriffe let me not be printed with a Brass pot on my head.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: March fair, march fair, afore good Captain Pantler.

lg.l: Oh man, or beast, or you at least
That were or brow or Autler,
Prick up your eares, unto the teares
Of me poor Paul the Pantler,
That thus am clipt, because I chipt
The cursed crust of Treason:
With loyal knife! Oh dolefull strife
To hang thus without reason.

div.head: The Bubble.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: The Master becomes a servant, the servant a Master, and the Master a servant agen.

sp.speaker: MAster.
sp.p: Hast thou packt up all thy things? nay prithee weep not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Affection Sir will burst out, but Master wherefore should we be parted?

sp.speaker: Master.
sp.p: Because my fortunes are desperate.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But whether do you mean to go Master?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: Why to Sea man, to sea.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Lord bless us methinks I hear of a tempest already.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Where dwells Mr. Bubble?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What is your business with Mr. Bubble? I am the Man.

sp.speaker: Messeng.
sp.p: May I be assured that your name is Mr Bubble?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I tell thee honest friend my name is Mr Bubble, Mr Bartholomew Bubble.

sp.speaker: Messeng.
sp.p: Why then Sir you are Heir to a million; your Uncle the rich Usurer is dead.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: How my little Bubble is blown up with the news.

sp.speaker: The other.
sp.p: Where's the Worshipfull Mr. Bubble?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The Worshipfull, what you do with the Worshipfull Mr. Bubble? I am the Man.

sp.speaker: Other Messeng.
sp.p: Mr. Thong the Beltmaker by me gives you notice that your Uncle is dead, and you are his only Heir.

lg.l: Thy news is good & I have look'd for't long,
Thanks unto thee my friend, and good man Thong:
Come Master now you shall not need to travell,
Nor feast your Toes with durt and scurvy Gravell.

div.stage: Enter in Mourning and a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: I, I, he's gone, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What then? 'tis not you can fetch him agen, it must be your comfort that he dyed well.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Truely so it is, I would to God I had ee'n another Uncle that would dye no worse, the remembrance of death is sharp Gentlemen, therefore there is a Banquet within to sweeten your conceits.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Bubble we'l go in and tast of your bounty, in the mean time you must be of good cheer.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p:
If greife take not away my stomack, I will have
good cheer.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: If griefe take not away my stomack I will have good cheer:— Sprinckle, Had the women puddens to their dole?

sp.speaker: Sprinckle.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: And how did they take them?

sp.speaker: Sprinckle.
sp.p: With their hands Sir.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: O thou Hercules of ignorance, I mean how were they satisfied?

sp.speaker: Sprinckle.
sp.p: By my troth Sir, but so so, and yet some of them had two.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: O insatiable Women! whom two puddins would not satisfie,

lg.l: Off with my mourning Robes, griefe to the grave,
For I have Gold and therefore will be brave: Pulls off his Mourning.
In Silkes I'le rattle it of every colour
And when I go by water, scorne a skullar:
In black cornation Velvet I will cloak me,
And when Men bid God save me, cry Tu Quoque:

sp.p: It is needfull a Gentleman should speak Latin some times, i'st not Gervase?

sp.speaker: Gervase.
sp.p: O very gracefull, your most accomplisht Gentlemen are known by it.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Then I'le use that little I have upon all accasions.

div.stage: Enter Bubble as to his Courtship▪ with Ladyes and their father.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Thankes, and Tu Quo is a word for all, but Gervase how shall I behave my selfe to the Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why advance your selfe towards them, and for your discourse your Tu Quoque will bear you out.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Nay, and that be all I care not, I'le set a good face on't that's flat, and here's a leg? if ever a Baker in England shew me a better I'le give him mine for nothing.

sp.speaker: Gervase.
sp.p:
Oh that's a special thing that I must caution you of, never whil'st you live commend your selfe, the more vilely you speak of your,— the more the Ladyes
will applaud.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Say'st thou so Gervase, then let me alone to dispraise my selfe, I'le make my selfe the a●…antest Coxcomb in a whole Countrey, is this the eldest sir

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes marry is she sir.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: I'le kisse the youngest first, because she likes me best, by th' masse they kisse exceeding well, I do not think out they have been brought up to 't,— now to my speech Lady— even a— Drumer or a Pewterer—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Do,— do, do.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What do they do?

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: By my troth I do not know; for to say truth I am a kind of an Asse.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How sir, an Asse?

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: So God ha' me I am Lady, you never saw an erranter Asse in your life, pray look upon me Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So I do sir.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: But look upon me well, and tell me if ever you saw a Man look so simply as I do, did you ever see a worse timber'd Leg, what say you, can you find e're a good inch about me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes that I can sir.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Find it and take it Lady; there I think I bob'd her Iervase,— come Ladies will you lead the way.

sp.speaker: Gervase.
sp.p: Ah while you live Men before VVomen, custome hath plai'd it so.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Why then custome is not so mannerly as I would be.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Pray let me see your hand, the line of your Maiden-head is out, now for your fingers; upon which finger will you weare your Wedding-ring.

sp.speaker: Mistresse.
sp.p: Upon no finger.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Then I perceive you mean to weare it upon your Thumb, well the time is come sweet Ioyce, the time is come.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: What to do sir.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: For me to tickle thy Tu Quoque, therefore prepare, provide to morne to meet me as a Bride.

sp.speaker: Mistresse.
sp.p: I'le meet thee like a Ghost first.

div.stage: Enter Scattergood, and Bubble as to be married.

sp.speaker: Scattergood.
sp.p: Did I eat my Lettice to Supper last night that I am so sleepy, thy eyes are close too Brother Bubble.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: As fast as a Kentish Oyster, surely I was begot in a Plumb-Tree, I have such a deale of Gum about my eyes, what's this about my shins?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: We have metamorphosed our Stoacking for want of Splendor.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Pray, what's that Splendor?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Why, 'tis the Latin word for a Christmas candle.

div.stage: Enter the Gentlewomen their Father and their Husband.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Tu Quoque to all: What shall we go to Church? I long to be about this geare.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: You may take out the other nap now, for you are cozen'd, and made a coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: That word coxcombe goes against my Stomack.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: And against mine, a man might have digested a Woodcock better.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Do you know that youth in Sattin, he's the penner to that Inkhorn.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Are not you my man Gervase? have you marryed her?

sp.speaker: Gervase.
sp.p: The Priest has Sir.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: Then am worse then ten Coxcombes.

sp.speaker: Gervase.
sp.p: And a beggerly one, your time of pageantry is over, sergeants take him to ye.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p: How's this, is my Tu Quoque come to an Et cetera

sp.speaker: Gervase.
sp.p: If you can put off your former pride and put on this with that humility that you first wore it, I will pay your debts, free you of all incumbrances, and take you again into my service.

sp.speaker: Bubble.
sp.p:
'Tis, but faces about, and be as I was, Tenter-hook let me go, I will take his Worships offer, rather then be kept in you clutches, a man in a Blew coat may have
some colour for his Knavery, when in the Counter he can have none.

div.head: The CLUB-MEN.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: An old Humorous Captain animates the rout to Rebellion on the behalf of Philaster, they surprise Pharamond, a boasting lamish Prince, but are appeased by Philaster, and Pharamond released.

div.p: COme my brave mirmidons, lets fall on, let our Caps swarme my boyes, and your nimble Tongues forget your Mother Gib-rish, of what do you lack, and set your mouths up Children, till your Pallats fall frighted halfe a fathome, past the cure of Bay-salt and grosse Pepper, and then cry Philaster, brave Philaster, let Philaster be deeper in request, my ding-dongs, my paires of dear Indentures, King of Clubs, then your cold water chamblets, or your paintings spitted with copper, let not your hasty silkes or your branch'd cloth of bodkin, or your tishnes, dearly belov'd of spiced Cake and Custard, your Robinhoods scarlet and Johns, tye your affections in darknesse to your shops, no dainty Duckers, up with your three-pil'd spirits, your wrought valours, and let your uncut coller make the King feele the measure of your mightinesse Philaster, cry my Rose-nobles cry.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Philaster, Philaster.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p:
How do you like this my Lord Prince, these
are mad boyes▪ I tell you, these are things that will not strike their Top-sailes to a foarst, and let a Man of Warre an Argosy bull, and cry Cockes.

sp.speaker: Phar.
sp.p: Why you rude slave, do you know what you do?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My pretty Prince of Puppets, we do know, and give your greatnesse warning, that you talk no more such bug-words, or that soldred Crown shall be scratch'd with a Musket; Deare Prince Pippin, down with your noble blood, or as I live I'le have you codled; let him lose my spirits, make as a round Ring with your Bills my Hectors, and let us see what this trim Man dares do; now sir have at ye, here I lie, and with this swashing blow, do you sweat Prince; I could hack your Grace, and hang ye up crosse-leg'd, like a Hare at a Poulterers.

sp.speaker: Phar.
sp.p: You will not see me murthered wicked Villains.

sp.speaker: 1 Citiz.
sp.p: Yes indeed we will sir, we have not seen one foe a great while.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He would have weapons, would he? give him a broadside my brave Boyes with your Pikes, branch me his skin in flowers like a Sattin, and between every flower a mortal cut, your Royalty shall ravell, jag him Gentlemen, I'le have him cut to the kell, then down the seames, oh for a whip to make him Galoom-laces, I'le have a Coach-whip.

sp.speaker: Phar.
sp.p: O spare me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, the Man begins to feare and know himselfe, he shall for this time only be seal'd up with a feather through his nose, that he may only see Heaven, and think whether he's going, nay my beyond Sea sir, we will proclaime you, you would be King; thou tender heire apparant to a Church-ale, thou sleight Prince of single scarce●…et; thou Royall ring-taile fit to fly at nothing but poor mens Poultrey, and every Boy beat thee from that too with his bread and butter.

sp.speaker: Phar.
sp.p: Gods keep me from these hell-hounds.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: Shall's geld him Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, you shall spare his dowcets my dear Donsells, as you respect the Ladyes let them flourish; the curses of a longing woman kills as speedy as a Plague Boyes,

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: I'le have a leg that's certain.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: I'le have an arme.

sp.speaker: 3. Citiz.
sp.p: I'le have his nose and at my own charge, build a Colledge and clap't upon the Gate.

sp.speaker: 4. Citiz.
sp.p: I'le have his little Gut to string a fit with, for certainly a royall Gut will sound like Silver.

sp.speaker: Phira.
sp.p: Would they were in thy belly, and I past my paine once.

sp.speaker: 5. Citiz.
sp.p: Good Captain let me have his liver to feed Ferrets.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who will have parcells els? speak.

sp.speaker: Phar.
sp.p: Good Gods consider me I shall be tortur'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: Captain I'le give you the trimming of your Hand-sword; and let me have his s●…in to make false scabbards.

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: He had no hornes Sir had he?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No Sir, he's a palla●…d, what would'st thou do with hornes?

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: O if he had, I would have made rare Hafts and whistles of 'em, but his vain bones if they be sound shall serve me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long long live Philaster, the brave Prince Philaster, I thank ye Gentlemen, but why are these rude weapons brought abroad? to teach your hands uncivill trades?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We are the royal Rosicleeze, we are thy mirmidons thy Guard, thy rourers, and when the Noble body is in durance, thus do we clap our musty murryons on, and trace the streets in terrour, ●…is it peace thou Mars of men? is the King sociable, and bids thee i●…e? Art thou above thy foemen and froe as Phebus? speak, of not, this stand of Royal Blood shall be broach, a tilt and run even to the lees of Honour.

sp.speaker: Philast.
sp.p: Hold and be satisfied, I am my selfe, free as my thoughts are: By the Gods I am.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Art thou the dainty Darling of the King? art thou the hylas to our Hercules? doth the Lords bow, and
the regarded Scarlets, kiss their gum'd gols and cry we are your servants? Is the Court navigable, and the presence struck with Flags of friendship? if not, we are thy Castle, and this man sleeps.

sp.speaker: Philaster.
sp.p: I am what I do desire to be your friend; I am what I was born to be your Prince.

sp.speaker: Pharo.
sp.p: Sir there is some humanity in you, you have a noble Soul forget my name, and know misery, set me safe aboard from these wild camballs, and as I live, I'le quit this Land for ever.

sp.speaker: Philast.
sp.p: I do pitty you: friends discharge your feares, deliver me the Prince.

sp.speaker: 1. Citiz.
sp.p: Good Sir take heed he does not hurt you, he's a fierce man I can tell you Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Prince by your leave, I'le have a surfingle, and make you like a hawk.

sp.speaker: Philast.
sp.p: Away, away, there is no danger in him, alas he had rather sleep to shake his fit off, good my friends go to your houses and by me have your pardons and my love and for an earnest drink this.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long may'st thou live brave Prince, brave Prince, brave Prince.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Thou art the King of Courtesies: fall off again my sweet youths, come, and every ne●…ce to his house agen, and hang his pewter up, then to the Tavern and bring your wives in muffs, we will have Musick, and the red Grape shall make us dance and rise boyes.

div.head: Forc'd VALLOUR.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: A Fellow that will never fight but when he is in paines with some displease is perswaded into one, and then doe, Wonders.

sp.speaker: LEontius.
sp.p: Go get the Drums, beat round Leiutenant.

sp.speaker: Leiute.
sp.p: Hark ye, Sir, I have a foolish business they call Marryage.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: After the Wars are done.

sp.speaker: Leiute.
sp.p: The Party stayes Sir, I have given the Priest his money too: all my friends Sir, my Father, and my Mother.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Will ye go forward.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: She brings a pretty matter with her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Halfe a douzen Bastards.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Some forty Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: A goodly competency.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I meane Sir, pounds a year; I'le dispatch the matter, 'tis but a night or two; I'le overtake ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Where lyes the horse quarter?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: And if it be a Boy, I'le even make bold Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Away with your whore, a plague o'your whore, damn'd Rogue, now you are cur'd and well; must ye be clicketing?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I have broke my mind to my ancient, in my absence, he's a sufficient Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Get forward.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Only receive her portion.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Get ye forward; els I'le bang ye forward.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Strange Sir, a Gentleman and an Officer, cannot have the liberty to do the Office of a man.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Shame light on thee, how came this whore into thy head?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: This whore Sir? 'tis strange, a very poor whore.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Do not answere me: Troop, troop away; Do not name this whore again, or think there is a whore.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: That's very hard Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Turne but thy face, and do but make Mouths at 'em.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: And have my teeth knockt out; I thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: what the divell ailes thee? dost long to be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Faith sir, I make no suit for't: but rather then I would live thus out of charity, continually in brawling.—
