sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And wilt thou ne're fight more?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: 'Ith mind I am in.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Nor never be sick again?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I hope I shall not.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Prithee be sick again; prithee, I beseech thee, be just so sick again.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I'le need'st be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: If all the arts that are can make a collique, therefore look to't; or if imposthums marke me, as big as foot balls.—

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Deliver me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: O●… stones of ten Pound weight 'ith Kidneys, through ease and ugly dyets may be gather'd; I'le feed ye up my selfe, I'le prepare ye, you cannot fight, unlesse the devill feares ye, you shall not want provocations, I'le scratch ye, I'le have thee have the Tooth-ach and the head-ach.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Good Collonel, I'le do any thing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No, no, nothing— then will I have thee blown with a pair of Smiths bellows, because you shall be sure to have a round Gale with ye, fil'd full of Oyle, o'devill, and aquafortis, and let these work, these may provoke.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Good Collonel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: A coward in full blood prithee be plaine with me, will roasting do thee any good?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Nor basting neither sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Marry that goes hard,— do you see that thing there▪

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: What thing? I see the brave Leiutenant.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Rogue what a name hast thou lost? be rul'd yet, I'le beat thee on; go winck and fight: a plague upon your sheepes heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: What's all this matter?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Nay I cannot shew ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There's twenty Pound, go but smell to 'em.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Alas sir, I have taken such a cold I can smell nothing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I can smell a rascall, a ranck rascall: fie how he stincks, stinks like a tyred jade.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Why that sir, do not you smell him?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Smell him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Stinks like a dead Dog, carrion— there's no such damnable smell under heaven as the faint sweat of a coward: will ye fight yet?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Nay, now I defye ye; ye have spoke the worst ye can of me, and if every man should take what you say to the heart—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: God a mercy, God a mercy with all my heart; here I forgive thee; and fight, or fight not, do but go along with us and keep my Dog.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I love a good Dog naturally.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: What's all this stir Leiutenant?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Nothing sir, but a sleight matter of argument.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Pox take thee: sure I shall love this Rogue, he's so pretty a Coward; come play fellow, come, prithee come up; come Chicken, I have a way shall fit yet; a tame knave; come, look upon us.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I'le tell you who does best boyes.

div.stage: Enter Leontius, and the two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: That he is sick again.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Extreamly sick; his disease grown incurable, never yet found, nor touch'd at.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Well we have it and here he comes.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: The Prince has been upon him what a platter face he has now? it takes, believe it; how like an Asse he lookes?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I feel no great pain, at least I think I do not; yet I feel sensibly I grow extreamly faint: how cold I sweat now?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: So, so, so.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p:
And now 'tis even too true, I feel a pricking, a pricking, a strange pricking: how it tingles? and as it were a stitch too: the Prince told
me, and every one cry'd out I was a dead man; I had thought I had been as well.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Upon him now boys, and do it most demurely.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: How now Leiutenant.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I thank ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Life, how lookes this man? how dost thou good Leiutenant?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: I ever told ye this man was never cur'd, I see it too plain now; how do ye feel your selfe? you look not perfect, how dull his eye hangs?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: That may be discontent.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Beleive me friend I would not suffer now the tithe of those paines this man feeles; marke his forehead, what a cloud of cold dew hangs upon't?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I have it, again I have it; how it growes upon me? a miserable man I am.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, a miserable man thou shalt be, this is the tamest trout I ever tickl'd.

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.p: This way he went.

sp.speaker: 2. Phis.
sp.p: Pray heaven we find him living, he's a brave fellow, 'tis pitty he should perish thus.

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.p: A stronge hearted man, and of a noble sufferance.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Ho, ho,

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: How now? how is it man.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen, never so full of pain.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Did I not tell ye?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Never so full of pain Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1. Phis.
sp.p: He is here; how do ye Sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Phis.
sp.p: Be of good comfort Souldier, the Prince has sent us to you.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Do you think I may live.

sp.speaker: 1. Phis.
sp.p: Yes you may live; but.—

sp.speaker: Leiut▪
sp.p: Finely butted Doctor.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Do not discourage him.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Here comes the Prince.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How now Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: bewailing Sir, a souldier, and one I Demetrius think your Grace will greive to part with, but every living think.—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Tis true, must perish, our lives are but our marches to our Graves, how dost thou now Leiutenant?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p:
Faith 'tis true Sir, we are but spans and candles
ends.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: He's finely mortified.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I see he alters strangely; and that a pace too, I saw it this morning in him, when he poor man I dare swear.—

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: No beleiv't sir, I never felt it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How he swells?

sp.speaker: 1. Phis.
sp.p: The imposthume fed with a new malignant humor now will grow to such a bigness, 'tis incredible, the compass of a Bushell will not hold it, and with such a hell of torture it will rise too.—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Can you endure me touch it?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Oh, I beseech you Sir? I feel you sensibly e're you come neer me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: He's finely wrought, he must be cut, no cure else, and suddenly, you see how fast he blowes out.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Good Mr. Doctor, let me be beholding to you, I feel I cannot last.

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.p: For what Leiutenant?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: But ev'n for halfe a douzen cans of good Wine, that I may drink my Will out; I faint hideously.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Fetch him some Wine, and since he must go Gentlemen, why let him take his journey merrily.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: That's even the neerest way.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Here off with that.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: These two I give your Grace, a poor remembrance of a dying man Sir, and I beseech you weare 'em out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I will souldier, these are five Legacies.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Among the Gentlemen, even all I have left; I am a poor man, naked, yet something for remembrance; four a peece Gentlemen, and lay my body where you please.

sp.speaker: Leon▪
sp.p: It will work.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I make your Grace my Executor, and I beseech you see my poor will fulfilled; sure I shall walk else.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: As full as they can be fill'd, here's my hand souldier.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I would hear a Drum beat but to see how I could endure it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Beat a Drum there.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Oh Heavenly musick, I would hear one sing to't, I am very full of pain.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Sing? 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Why, then I would drink a Drum full; where lies the Enemy?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p:
Why, here close
by.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Now he begins to master.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: And dare ye fight? dare ye fight Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1. Phis.
sp.p: You must not cut him: he's gone then in a moment, all the hope left, is to worke his weakness into sudden anger, and make him raise his passion above his paine, and so dispose him on the Enemy; his body then being stir'd with violence, will purge it selfe and break the sore.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Tis true sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Phis.
sp.p: And then my life for his.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: I will not die thus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: But he is too weak to do.—

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Die like a Dog?

sp.speaker: 1. Phis.
sp.p: I he's weak but yet he's heart-hole.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Hem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: An excellent signe.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Hem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Stronger still, and better.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Hem, hem; Ran, tan, ran, tan, tan.

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.p: Now he's 'ith way on't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well go thy wayes, thou wilt do something certaine.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And some brave thing, or let mine Eares be cut off.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Fetch him off, fetch him off; I'm sure he's clouted; did I not tell you how 'twould take?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis admirable

div.stage: Enter Leiutenant with colours in his hand, persuing 3 or 4. souldiers.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Follow that blow my friend, there's at your Coxcombs, I fight to save me from the surgeons miseries.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How the knave curryes 'em?

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: You cannot Rogues, till you have my diseases, fly my fury, ye bread and butter Rogues, do you run from me? and my side would give me leave, I would so hunt ye, ye porredg-gutted slaves, ye Veal-broth boobies.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Enough, enough Leiutenant, thou hast done bravely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Mirror of man.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: There's a Flag for ye Sir, I tooke it out o'th shop, and never paid for't I'le to 'em again, I am not come to'th text yet.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.p: No more my souldier: beshrew my heart he is hurt sore.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Hang him he'l lick all those whole.

sp.speaker: 1. Phis.
sp.p: Now will we take him, and cure him a trice.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Be carefull of him.

sp.speaker: Leiut.
sp.p: Let me live but two yeares, and do what ye will with me: I never had but two houres yet of happynes,; pray ye give me nothing to provoke my Valour, for I am ev'n as weary of this fighting▪—

sp.speaker: 2. Phis.
sp.p: You shall have nothing; come to the Princes Tent, and there the Surgeons presently shall search ye, then to your rest.

sp.speaker: Leiut. Leiut.
sp.p: A little hansome Litter to lay me in, and I shall sleep.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Look to him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I do beleive a horse begot this fellow, he never knew his strength yet.

div.head: The Encounter.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: A peece of M●…ck-Knight errantry performed between Ralfe a Grocers Prentice and Barbarossa a Barber.

list.head: ACTORS NAMES.
list.item: a Squire and Dwarffe attending upon the Knight,
distressed Damsells delivered by the Pussiant Knight of the Burning Pestle.

sp.speaker: RAFE.
sp.p:
Oh faint not heart, Susan my Lady deare: the Coblers Maid in Milk-street for whose sake, I take these Arms, O let the thought of thee, carry thy Knight through all the adventerous Deeds, and in the honour of thy beauteous selfe, may I destroy this monster Barbarosso,
knock Squire upon the Bason, till it break with the shrill strokes, or till the Grant speak.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O George the Giant, the Giant, now Rafe for thy life.

sp.speaker: Barbar.
sp.p: What fond unknowing wight is this that dares, so rudely knock at Barbarosso's cell, where no man comes, but leaves his fleece behind?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: I, Trayterous caitife, who am sent by fate to punish all the sad enormities thou hast commited against Ladies gentle, and errant Knights, Traytor to heaven and men: prepare thyselfe, this is the dismall hour appointed for thee, to give strict account of all thy beastly treacherous villanies.

sp.speaker: Barbar.
sp.p: Fool hardy Knight, full soon thou shalt aby this fond reproach thy body will I bang, and loe upon that string shall hang: prepare thy selfe, for dead soon shalt thou be.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Saint George for me.

sp.speaker: Barbar.
sp.p: Gargantua for me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: To him Rafe to him, hold up the Giant, set out thy leg before Rafe.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: Falsifie a blow

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: falsifie a blow, the Giant lies open on the left side.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Bear't off, bear't off still; there boy, O Rafe's almost down, Rafe's almost down.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Susan inspire me, now have up again.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Up, up, up, so Rafe, down with him, down with him Rafe.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: Fetch him over the hip boy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: There boy, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill Rafe.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: No Rafe get all out of him first.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p:
Presumptious man, see to what desperate end thy treachery hath brought thee, the just Gods, who never prosper those that do despise them, for all the villanies which thou hast done to Knights and Ladies, now have paid thee home by my stiffe Arme, a Knight adventurous; but say vile wretch before I send thy soul to sad avernus, whether it must go, what captives holds't thou
thy sable Cave?

sp.speaker: Barbar.
sp.p: Go in and free them all, thou hast the day.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Go Squire and Dwarffe, search in this dreadfull Cave, and free the wretched Prisoners from their bonds.

sp.speaker: Barbar.
sp.p: I crave for mercy, thou art a Knight, and scorn'st to spill the blood of those that beg.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Thou shewest no mercy, nor shalt thou have any, prepare thy self for thou shalt surely die.

div.stage: Enter Squire leading one winking with a Bason under his Chine.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Behold brave Knight here is one prisoner, whom this wild man hath used as you see.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This is the wisest word I heard the Squire speak.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Speak what thou art, and how thou hast been us'd, that I may give him condigne punishment.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.p: I am a Knight that took my journey post northward from London, and in courteous wise, this Giant train'd me to his den, under pretence of killing of the Itch, and all my body with a powder strew'd, that smarts and stings, and cut away my beard, and my curl'd locks wherein were Ribands ty'd, and with a water washt my tender eyes, whil'st up and down about me still he skipt, whose vertue is▪ that till my eyes be wipt with a dry cloth▪ for this my foul disgrace, I shall not dare to look a Dog i'th face.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Alas poor Knight releife him Rafe, releife poor Knights whil'st you live.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: My trusty Squire convey him to the Town where he may find releife, adue fair Knight.

div.stage: Enter Dwarffe leading one with a Patch on his Nose.

sp.speaker: Dwarffe.
sp.p: Pussiant Knight of the Burning Pestle hight, see here another wretch, whom this foul beast hath scorcht and scor'd in this unhumane wise.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Speak me thy name, and eke thy place of birth, and what hath been thy usage in this Cave?

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.p:
I am a Knight Sir Pock-hole is my name, and
by my birth I am a Londoner, free by my Copy, but my Ancestors were Frenchmen all, and riding hard this way, upon a trotting horse my bones did ake, and I faint Knight to ease my weary limbs, light at this Cave, when straight this furious fiend, with sharpest Instrument of purest steel, did cut the Gristle of my Nose away, and in the place this velvet plaster stands, releive me gentle Knight out of his hands.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good Rafe releive Sir Pock-hole, and send him away, for in truth his breath stinks.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Convey him st aight after the other Knight, Sir Pock-hole fare you well.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.p: Kind Sir good night.

div.stage: Exit. cries within deliver us women 〈◊〉 us women deliver us:

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Harke George, what a wofull cry there is I think some Women lyes in there.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: What gastly noise is this? speak Barbarossa, or by this blazing steel thy head goes off.

sp.speaker: Barbar.
sp.p: Prisoners of mine, whom I in dyet keep, send lower down into the Cave, and in a Tub that's heated smoaking hot, there may they find them and deliver them.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Run Squire and Dwarffe, deliver them with speed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But will not Rafe kill this Giant, surely I am afraid if he let him go he will do as much hurt, as ever he did.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: Not so mouse neither, if he could convert him. I George, if he could convert him; but a Giant is not so soon converted as one of us ordinary people. There's a pretty tale of a Witch, that had the divells marke about her, God bless us, that had a Giant to her son, that was called Lob— ly— by— the fire, didst never hear it George. Citiz. Peace Nell here comes the prisoners.

div.stage: Enter Squire leading a man with a glass of potion in his hand, and the Dwarffe leading a woman with dyet-bread and drink.

sp.speaker: Dwarffe.
sp.p: Here be these pined wretches manfull Knight, that for these six weekes have not seen a wight.

lg.l: Deliver what you are, and how you came
To this sad Cave, and what your usage was.
I am an Errant-Knight that follow'd Arms,
With Spear and Sheild; and in my tender years,
I stricken was with Cupid's fiery Shaft,
And fell in love with this my Lady dear,
And stole her from her Friends in Turnbal-street,
And bore her up and down from Town to Town,
Where we did eat and drink, and Musick hear:
Till at the length, at this unhappy Town
We did arrive; and coming to this Cave,
This Beast us caught, and put us in a Tub;
Where we this two months sweat, and should have done
Another moneth, if you had not reliev'd us.
This Bread and Water hath our Diet been;
Together with a Rib cut from a Neck
Of burned Mutton. Hard hath been our Fare:
Release us from this ugly Giants Snare.
This hath been half the food we have receiv'd;
But onely twice a day for novelty,
He gave a spoonful of his hearty Broath
To each of us, through this same tender Quill.
From this infernal Monster you shall go,
That useth Knights and Gentile-Ladies so.
Convey 'em hence
Mercy, great Knight: I do recant my ill;
And henceforth never Gentile-Blood will spill.
I give thee Mercy: but yet thou shalt swea●…
Upon my Burning Pestle, to perform
Thy promise utter'd.

sp.speaker: Barbár.
sp.p: I swear and kiss.

lg.l: Depart then, and amend.
Come, Squire and Dwarf, the Sun grows towards his set;
And we have many more Adventures yet.

div.head: The Humour of Simple.

argument.head: Argument needless,
argument.p: It being a Thorow Farce, and very well known.

sp.speaker: Old Simpleton.
sp.p: SIrrah Simpleton, where are you?

sp.speaker: Young Simpleton within.
sp.p: Here, here, Father.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Where, where, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: At the Cupboard, Father; at the Cupboard.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: I thought as much: but come you hither, Sirrah, or I shall make your Ears sing Prick-song for you.

div.stage: Enter Young Simpleton with a great piece of Bread and Butter.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: 'Tis a miserable condition that a man cannot eat a little bit for his After-noons Lunchin, but he must be disturbed in the best of his Stomach.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: A bit! dost thou call it? O' my Conscience this devouring Rascal, old as I am, would eat me if he found me in the Cupboard.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p:
I do not think there is such a genteel Smith in the Town, that hath such an old niggardly Coxcomb
to his Father as I: he knows I have no better a stomach then a young Green-sickness Girl, and yet he grutches me every bit I eat.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Leave off your muttering, and lend me an Ear a while.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Truly I cannot spare one, Father: yet now I think on't, you have great occasion for one ever since the last Pillory-day; but since you are my Father, I will vouchsafe to listen a while.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: You know that I am old.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: The more's the pity that you were not hang'd while you were young.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Thou hast drunk most of my Means away.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: I' ll eat out the rest.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Leave your ill breeding, and give me sensibly a Reason why you will not work.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Because I am lazie, Father.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Nay, that's true.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: True? why, do you think I would be so unmannerly to tell you a Lye, Father?

sp.speaker: O. Simp.
sp.p: How I shall maintain that coming stomach of yours, unless your self endeavour for it, I know not: but if thou wilt be ruled, I 'll make thee a Man.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: A Man! why what am I now, a Mouse? what would you make of me?

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: An Asse, an Asse, a gross Asse.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: You may well make me a gross Asse, you have so good a pattern.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Listen to me: you know the Widows Daughter at the Corner, sweet Mistriss Dorothy; she's both young and handsome, and has money too.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: I, and that will help to buy victuals.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Go and woo her, and I dare lay my Life thou carriest her.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p:
I carry her, Father? Alas! I have but a
weak back, and besides I am somewhat lazily given, as you say: it were a great deal better that she would carry me.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Thou hast no more wit then my Hammers head has, and no more brains then an Anvil, which every one may strike on, but never move it: Go, take your Fiddle, at that they say you are excellent; and when she thanks thee from her Chamber-window, say thou art my son, and that I sent thee about the thing she wots of.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: O must I bumfiddle her under her Chamber-window? Well, I will go wash my hands, and starch my face, because I may be sure to go cleanly about my business.

div.stage: Enter Young Simpleton with a Viol.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Now must I go play an Alampadoe under Mistriss Dorothy's Chamber-window, and all that time perhaps she is a snorting: for to say the truth, my Musick will hardly have the vertue to waken her; and if she should wake, I could not tell what to say to her, unless it were to desire her to go to bed again. And because I will be sure to be acceptable to her, I will joyn my Nightingale-Voyce thereunto.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: What Slave is this presumes to court my Mistriss? Could I but see him, I would satisfie my anger with the ruine of his limbs; but he is gone, and I loose time in seeking.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: That was a roaring Rogue, he has made my Heart jump upright into my Mouth; and if I had not held it fast with my Teeth, without doubt it had forsaken my Body; but he is gone, and now I will venture forward.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p:
I heard some Musick at my Sweet-hearts window: could I but finde him, I would cut him, and slash
him till his whole body were anatomized: but he is gone, and it was his wisest course.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: That roaring Rogue was far worse then the t' other; he has almost frighted my Song out of my head. Oh! we true and faithful Lovers, what perils and dangers must we undergo, to gain the wills and affections of our dearest Dears? But now to my Musick; and because she shall take a great pleasure to think on it, I will sing a song of a young Wench that had a great minde to be married before her time.

lg.l: Oh! Mother let me have a Husband kinde, with toitre, loytre, loitre.
That day and night I may comfort finde of a toitre, &c.
I care not whether honest Man or Knave, so that he keep me fine and brave,
And that none else but I may have his toitre, &c.
Oh Daughter you are not old enough for a toitre, &c.
And Husbands often do prove rough with a toitre, &c.
Your tender heart no grief can carry, as they must do sometimes that marry:
You yet may well a twelve-moneth tarry for a toitre, &c.
Oh! Mother I am in my teens, for a toitre, &c.
And younger Wives are often seen with a toitte, &c.
I pray let me not so idle stand, for I can do as well as any can,
I have had a proof with John our Man of his toitre, &c.

sp.p: Well, if she does not run mad for me now, it is pity she should have Musick under her VVindow as long as she lives.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Oh is it you? I thought none but a Puppy like your self, would have disturbed the Neighbours with your Gridiron-musick: a Saw were far more pleasing.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Forsooth I am very sorry that you have no better skill in Musick; in my Opinion I sung most melodiously: but if you will be pleased to look with Eyes of judgement upon me, you will express your love in a better manner to me.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I shall express my love, if you continue here, in a far worser manner then you think for. Do you see this Chamber-pot? it longs to be acquainted with that brainless head of yours: therefore be gone, and save your self a washing.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: If you should wash me, I think it would be but labour in vain: yet if you please to distil any of your sweet water upon me, I shall desire to be smelt out by you.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: You Asse, you Puppy; must you needs force a drowning?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Is this the beginning of love? It is almost as bad as the Proverb to me: stay, it may be it is Rose-water. Voh, it is as rank Urine as ever any Doctor cast. I'll call this same Old Simpleton my Father that set me about this business. Oh, Father Simpleton, where are you?

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Oh my Son, how hast thou sped, Boy?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: O! I have sped most abominably, Father: I got a great deal more then I expected.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Oh my own natural Boy!

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: I, natural, to be sure, I had ne'er come here else.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: But how did she relish thee?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Why she relish'd me with a whole Chamber-pot full of water.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: VVhy thou Asse, thou Puppy, thou Fool, thou Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: VVhy? how can I help it? why did you get me so like a Fool?

sp.speaker: O Simpl.
sp.p: Come, shew me to her, and you shall see how I will handle her.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Nay, Father, I should be loath to marry her, after you have had the handling of her.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: This is her Chamber, is it not?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Yes: I know it by a good token; for here she opened the Sluce, and let the Flood-gates out upon me.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Mistriss Dorothy, Mistriss Dorothy, pray come to the window.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Pray to the window, Mistriss Dorothy.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Sirrah, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: VVhat again? sure this whole morning is nothing but my trouble: what VVise-aker is that now?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: She calls you VVise-aker: speak now.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: I am your Neighbour, Old Simpleton the Smith.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: And I Young Simpleton the Smith.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Oh Neighbour, is it you? Here was your Son but now, and he kept a worse noise then a Bear-baiting: but you are civil, I will come down to you.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Look you there, Sirrah; she will come down to me, she says.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: I, by that time I have been a Courtier as long as you have been, one woman or other may come down to me.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Good morrow, Neighbour: what is your business, pray?

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: VVhy it is this: this is my Son. Nay, it is my Son, I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Yes, forsooth, he is sure I am his Son; my Mother told him so.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Now I look better on him, he seems to me more handsome then before; your company seasons him with discretion: but what's your business, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: VVhy, if you please, forsooth, I would fain joyn you two together in the way of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, to mock a marriage.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: But hold, Sir, two words to a bargain: what profession is your Son of?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Forsooth I am a Blacksmith: and though I say it, I have as good VVorking-gear as any Smith in the Parish; all my Neighbours VVives shall be my witness.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Sirrah, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: VVhy, shall I come a wooing, and say nothing for my self?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: But what Estate, I pray, has your Son in posse?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Father, what Estate have I in a posset?

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Forsooth, two Cowes you shall have with him.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: VVith a Calf, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Four Ewes and Lambs, and a Horse to ride to market on.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Yes, and an A—No, now I think on it, you may keep your Asse your self.

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: Four Mark in money.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Do you mark that?

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: VVith a Bed and Blankets.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: And then we may daunce the shaking of the sheets when we can.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: These promises are fair; and if performed, I hope I shall not need repent my bargain.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Nor I neither: Come, let's to bed presently, and afterwards we'll talk on it.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: No, no; first to Church, and then to bed.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Oh! then you wo'nt follow the fashion of our Country; we commonly go to bed first, and to Church when we can: but come, I am contented.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: What should this mean? Doll has a Hat on: she did not use to wear one.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen! though I desire your company, yet now I could heartily wish your absence.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Why? what's the matter, Doll?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I am married.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Do you not know him? Young Simpleton the Smith.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: That Fool, that Coxcomb: I'll break his Hammer with his own jolt-head.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Stand close, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, now we are married, things ought to be well carried: and the first thing we should take care for, is, how to get Victuals. VVhat's that?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Nothing but the Rats and Mice.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: As sure as I live, I'll lay a trap for those Rats. But what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Nothing but the Neighbours Dogs.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: 'Tis a thousand pities but such Curs were hang'd up presently.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen, I would you were out of the House; for I am afraid he will return again ere I can handsomely shut the door.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl. within.
sp.p: VVhy Doll, Doll!

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Come ye behind me presently; I pray dispatch.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Doll, I have considered, that to set up my Trade is the way to get Victuals; and I want nothing of my Tools, but onely a pair of Bellows.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Fear not, Husband, I have a little money that you know not of; and if I can but hear of a good bargain, I will not fail to buy a pair of Bellows.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Oh thou pretty loving kinde Pigsnie! but what makes thee wear thy Coats of that fashion?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Do not you know, Husband, it is the fashion 〈◊〉 new-married VVives?

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Is it so? it is an excellent fashion in the Summer-time: but I'll go out, and return presently.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: VVhat will you do? 'tis ten to one he spies you, and then my reputation runs a hazard.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Appoint what way you will, we are contented.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I see him coming back; and truth to say, the course I shall advise, will seem a strange one, yet it must be: you know he did appoint that I should buy for him a pair of Bellows; now if you two can beat it lustily, and blow it strongly, this visit may be kept off from his knowledge.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Nay, any thing, good Doll; we cannot now be chusers.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: So, lie down: I'll fetch a Chafingdish of Charcoal hither, and practise you a while before he come.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I have plaid many a mad prank in my Life, yet ne'er till now acted a pair of Bellows.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: So, so, blow lustily, and fear not.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: VVife, I have considered with my self, that if we lay out all the mony in a pair of Bellows, we should have little or nothing left to buy Victuals.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Oh Husband, you are deceived; for I have bought you a pair of Bellows, the whole Town shews not a neater.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Is this a pair of Bellows? let me see, this is an a-la-moda pair of Bellows. But look you, Doll, when the Bellows-mender comes by, let him stop this hole here; for the winde comes out abominably. I'll call my Father Simpleton to see this pair of Bellows. Father, father, come hither.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: Did you ever see such a pair of Bellows as my VVife has bought?

sp.speaker: O. Simpl.
sp.p: A pair a Bellows, Son! Me-thinks this would serve better for an Anvil: Let's try how it will bear our stroaks.

sp.speaker: Y. Simpl.
sp.p: VVell, a match.

div.head: The Humour of Bumpkin.

argument.head: Argument needless,
argument.p: It being a Thorow Farce, very well known.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: WHy, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bumpkin.
sp.p: Nay, I know not: but every day my great Guts and my small Guts make such a Combustion in my Belly as passes, and my Puddings (like Lances) run a-tilt at my heart, and make me as queasie-stomacht as a young Green-sickness Girl newly come to a Big-belly.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: Canst thou not guess the reason of this trouble?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Yes, I think I can, and I'll be judged by thee, if my case be not desperate; I have a horrible minde to be in love.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: VVith whom?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: VVith any body; but I cannot finde out the way how to be in Love.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: VVhy? I'll instruct thee: Canst thou be melancholy?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Yes, as a Dog, or a Hog-louse: I could even finde in my heart to cry presently.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: Canst thou sleep well?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I never saw my self sleep.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: Is't possible, that thou who hast so long been an attendant upon my Lord Actaeon, shouldst be to learn the way to be in love?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: I would it were not possible, on the condition thou wert hanged and quartered.

lg.l: I thank you, Sir. But Bumpkin, list to me;
This day thou know'st the Maids and Young-men meet
To sport, and revel it about the May-pole;
Present thy self there; tell thy cause of grief;
And I dare warrant thee a Sweet-heart presently.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: If thou canst do that, I'll marry her first, and learn to love her afterwards.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: Haste thither, Bumpkin; I'll go on before.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: And I will follow thee a Dog-trot.

Is it not pity▪ that a Man of Authority as I am, having been chief Dog-keeper to my Lord Actaeon this five years, being a Man so comely of person, and having such a pure Complexion, that all fair Ladies may be ashamed to look on me, and that I should be distressed for a Sweet-heart? May-pole, I come;

lg.l: And if the Wenches there encrease my pains,
And scorn to love, I'll beat out all their brains.

div.stage: Enter Huntsmen with three Country Wenches.

sp.speaker: 2 Co. Wench.
sp.p: Is it possible, would Bumpkin be in love?

lg.l: Yes, if he knew but how; and for that sickness
I have undertaken to become his Doctor:
For, at the May-pole-meeting 'tis decreed,
A Sweet-heart must be purchast, come what will on't.

sp.speaker: 3 Co. Wench.
sp.p: Nay, if he be distressed, twenty to one he may finde charitable Persons there.
Come, strike up a Farewel to Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: That is a Dance that I could never hit of: pray desist a while, and hear my doleful Tale.

sp.speaker: 1 Co. Wench.
sp.p: He'll make us cry sure.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Be it known unto all men by these presents.

sp.speaker: 2 Co. Wench.
sp.p: An Obligation? we will be no witnesses.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Why then I'll hang my self.

sp.speaker: 3 Co. Wench.
sp.p: VVe will be witness then.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: VVhat, to my hanging? O'my Conscience, if I should woo my heart out, I should never be the fatter for it.— VVhere's your promise now?

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: You have not yet exprest your self; be plain; tell them your grief, a remedy will follow.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: If that be all, 'tis but an easie matter; pray take notice that I am in love— with some body.

sp.speaker: 2 Co. Wench.
sp.p: Would I were she!

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: VVhy? so you are, if you have a minde to it.

sp.speaker: 2 Co. Wench.
sp.p: Why then you are my own.

sp.speaker: 3 Co. Wench.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sister, I bespake him yesterday.

div.stage: They all hang about him. Goes to her.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Yes marry did she.

sp.speaker: 1 Co. Wench.
sp.p: But I was she that won him at the May-pole.

sp.speaker: 2 Co. Wench.
sp.p: Was that the cause you strove so for the Garland?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: What's that to you?
Would I had any one of them in quietness.

sp.speaker: 3 Co. VVench.
sp.p: But yet I must have share.

sp.speaker: 1 Co. VVench.
sp.p: So must I too.

sp.speaker: 2 Co. VVench.
sp.p: I will not part without the better half.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Then who shall have me whole? what, are you mad?

sp.speaker: 3 Co. VVench.
sp.p: There's reason for a madness in this case.

sp.speaker: 1 Co. VVench.
sp.p: I will not loose my right: Let go, I say.

sp.speaker: 2 Co. VVench.
sp.p: He shall be mine, or else he shall be nothing.

lg.l: Away you Burrs, why do you stick thus on me?
Now by this hand, if nothing can perswade you,
I'll drown my self for spight, that you may perish.
Hark, hark, my Lord Actaeons warning-piece;
That Horn gives us intelligence he does intend
To spend this day in hunting: Bumpkin, why stay you?
The hounds will quarrel with you: we'll come after.

sp.speaker: 1 Co. VVench.
sp.p: Will you not stay, my Love?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: I'll see you hang'd first; and by this hand, ere I will be in love again, I will feed my hounds with my own proper carcase.

sp.speaker: 2 Co. VVench.
sp.p: Now he is gone, our dancing may go forward.

sp.speaker: 2 Hunt.
sp.p: My Lord Actaeon stays; be quick, I pray.

sp.speaker: 3 Co. VVench.
sp.p: Quick as you will; the doing of it quick, makes it shew the better.

sp.speaker: Actaeon.
sp.p: Be nimble, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Nimble? yes, as a Bear that hath been lug'd to purpose: if Love be such a troublesome Companion, I will entreat him to keep out of my company.

sp.speaker: Actaeon.
sp.p: VVe consume the day.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: They have saved me a labour.

lg.l: Fie, what mean you?
The glory of this day calls us to action.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunt.
sp.p: Sir, you may please to know, that yesternight I lodged a Boar within the neighbouring Forest.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and I lodged a Fox at a house hard by.

div.head: The Humours of Simpkin.

argument.p: A continued Farce.

lg.l: BLind Cupid hath made my heart for to bleed:
Fa la, la, la, la, la, la, la, la.
But I know a man can help you at need:
With a fa la, la, la, la, la, la, la, la, la, la.
My husband he often a hunting goes out:
Fa la, la, &c.
And brings home a great pair of horns, there's no doubt:
With a fa la, la, la, &c.
How is't, Monsieur Simpkin? why are you so sad?
Fa la, la, la, &c.
I am up to the ears in love, and it makes me stark mad:
With a fa la, la, la, &c.
I am vext, I am tortur'd, and troubled at heart:
Fa la, la, &c.
But I'll try my skill to take off your smart:
With a fa la, la, &c.
And on that condition I give you a kiss:
Fa la, la, &c.
But what says your husband when he hears of this?
With a fa la, la, &c.
You know my affections, and no one knows more:
Fa, la, la, &c.
'Uds niggers noggers who knocks at the door?
With a fa, la, la, &c.
There is a Royster at the Door,
he seems a Fellow stout.
I do beseech you, worthy Friend,
which is the back-way out?
He swears and tears he will come in,
and nothing shall him hinder.
I fear he'll strip me out my skin,
and burn it into Tinder.
I have consider'd of a way,
and 'twill be sure the best.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: What may it be, my dearest Dear?

lg.l: Creep into this same Chest. A Chest set out.
And though he roar, speak you no word,
if you'll preserve my favour.
Shut to the Chest, I pray, with speed;
for something has some savour.
I never shall be quiet if
she use me in this fashion.
I am here to bid you welcome;
what mean you by this passion?
With some young sweet-fac'd Fellow,
I thought gone out you were.
No sooth, the sweet-fac'd Fellow
is kept a Prisoner here.
Where is the Fool thy Husband?
say, whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The Wittal is a hunting.

lg.l: Then we two are alone.
But should he come, and finde me here, what might the Cuckold think?
Perhaps he'd call the Neighbours in.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And beat you till you stink.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: Yet in the bloody War full oft, my courage I did try.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I know you have kill'd many a man.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You lye, you Slut, you lye.

lg.l: I never came before a Foe,
By night nor yet by day,
But that I stoutly rouz'd my self.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And nimbly ran away.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: Within this Chest I'll hide my self, if it chance he should come.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O no, my Love, that cannot be.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I have bespoke the room.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I have a place behinde here, which yet is known to no man.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She has a place before too, but that is all too common.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Wife, wherefore is the door thus barr'd? what mean you, pray, by this?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Alas, it is my Husband.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I laugh now till I piss.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: Open the Chest, I'll into it, my Life else it may cost.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Alas, I cannot open it.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I believe the Key is lost.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: I have bethought my self upon a dainty trick.

lg.l: What may it be, my dearest Love?
I prethee now be quick.
You must say that your Enemy into this house is fled;
And that your heart can take no rest until that he be dead.
Draw quickly out your furious Blade, and seem to make a strife:
Swear all th' excuses can be made, shall not preserve his Life.
Say that the Rogue is fled in here, that stole away your Coin;
And if I'll not deliver him, you'll have as much of mine.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: Here's no man but my self, on whom shall I complain?

lg.l: This great fool does not understand, this thing you must but seign.
My husband thus must be deceiv'd, and afterwards we'll laugh.
Wife, since you will not ope the Door,
I'll break't ope with my staff.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: Good woman shew me to the Slave, his limbs I strait will tear.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: By all the honesty I have, there's no man came in here▪

lg.l: VVhen I have fought to purchase wealth, and with my blood did win it,
This Rogue has got my purse by stealth.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But never a peny in it.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: She's big with Childe, therefore take heed you do not fright my wife.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: But know you who the Father is?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The Roarer, on my Life.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: She knows not of your enemy, then get you gone you were best.

lg.l: Peace, husband, peace; I tell you true▪
I have hid him in the Chest.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: I am glad on't at my heart, but do not tell him so.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: I would not for a thousand pound the Roarer should it know.

lg.l: VVhen next we meet, his life is gone, no other must he hope;
I'll kill him whatsoere comes on't.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Pray think upon a Rope.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: VVhat kinde of person is it then, that in the Chest doth lie?

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: A goodly handsome sweet young man, as ere was seen with eye.

lg.l: Then let us both entreat of him—
Pray put us not in fear:
VVe do beseech you go from hence.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: But tomorrow I'll be here.

lg.l: VVife, run with all the speed you can, and quickly shut the door;
I would not that the roaring Man should come in any more.
Mean time I will release the youth, and tell him how we have sped—
Be comforted my honest friend.
Alas, I'm almost dead.
My heart is tortur'd in my breast, with sorrow, fear and pain.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: I'll fetch some Aqua vitae, to comfort you again.

lg.l: And 'cause I will require you, whose love doth so excel,
I'll graft a pair of horns on your head▪ that may defend it well.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: Good husband, let the man stay here, 'tis dangerous in the street.

lg.l: I would not for a Crown of Gold the Roarer should him meet.
For should he come by any harm, they'd say the fault were mine.

sp.speaker: VVife to Simp.
sp.p: There's half a crown, pray send him out to fetch a quart of wine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's money for you, Sir,— pray fetch a quart of Sack.

lg.l: 'Tis well, 'tis well, my honest friend,
I'll see you shall not lack.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: But if he should dishonest me, for there are such slippery men.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Then he gets not of his half crown, one peny back agen.

lg.l: Thy husband being gone, my Love, we'll sin●… we'll dance and laugh:
I am sure he's a good fellow, and takes delight to quaff.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: I'll fold thee in my arms, my Love, no matter for his listning.

div.stage: The old man and his servant listen.

sp.speaker: Simpl.
sp.p: Gentlemen, some forty weeks hence you may come to a Christning.

lg.l: O Sirrah, have I caught you? now do the best you can;
Your School-master ne'er taught you to wrong an honest man.
Good Sir, I never went to school, then why am I abused?
The truth is, I am but a Fool, and like a Fool am used.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Yet Sirrah you had wit enough to think to Cuckold me.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: I jested with him, husband, his knavery to see.

lg.l: But now you talk of knavery,
I pray where is my sack?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: You shall want it in your belly, Sir, and have it on your back.

div.head: The Humour of Hobbinal.

argument.head: Argument is needless,
argument.p: Onely the Drollery taken out.

div.stage: Enter Dorilas, Strephon spying Hobbinal reading.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: WHat Paper is that he ruminates upon? Let us observe a little.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange thing I finde my self out every day more then other, to be one of the understanding'st, sweetest, neatest, and compleatest Shepherds that ever took hook in hand. T'other day I saw my face in a pail of water, and I had much ado to forbear drowing of my self. 'Tis no wonder then, that the beauteous Nymph Oenone makes much of me, and lets all the other Shepherds shake their Ears like Asses: and the truth is, if I can finde never a handsomer, she shall serve the turn. This was her birth-day, she being born in the year— one thousand six hundred,— nay hold a little: but on this day of the moneth it was, VVinter or Summer, in the honour of which we all keep holiday: and therefore for the credit of her beauty, and the honour of my own Poetry, I have made such a Copy of Verses on her, as will make her a thousand times handsomer then ever she was in her Life.
I will peruse them now with the eyes of understanding.

lg.l: OEnone fair, whose beauty does enrich us,
Tell me the cause why thou dost so bewitch us.
On this day thou wert born, though not begotten;
This day I'll think on when thou art dead and rotten.
And though thy coyness, and thy pretty scorn,
Makes many wish that thou hadst ne'er been born;
Yet for my own part, this I'll swear and say,
I wish thy time of birth were every day.

sp.p: If she do not run mad for love of me now, 'tis pity she should have Verses made on her as long as she lives.

sp.speaker: Streph.
sp.p: Let's interrupt him.— Hobbinal, well met.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But why so strange, man? I hope you will remember we are your fellow-Shepherds.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: You were once: but now I command you to know, I am a Master-Shepherd; for the fair Nymph Oenone, that makes all your mouths run over with water, does acknowledge me to be both Master and Mistress.

sp.speaker: Streph.
sp.p: In part 'tis true: yet if you well consider, she makes you but her sport; no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: If she make me her sport, 'tis more then ever she can make of thee: for thou art one of the sowrest lookt fellows that ever crept out of a Vinegar-bottle.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Here comes the fairest Idae ever nourisht.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Now will I see who is the most deserving Shepherd in all the Vale of Idae.— Little Rogue, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Oenone.
sp.p: O Hobbinal, you are welcome; I thought you had forgot me: you are my sport, and should be ever near me.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Look you there, I am her sport, she says: when will she give any of you such an honourable Title? but Sport, I do not think but thou art a Conjurer, or a VVitch, or a Devil at least: for thou hast insused such a combustion of Poetry in my head, that I fear I shall never be my own Man agen, nor my Master's neither.— There's a Copy of Verses, read 'em: nay, they are my own, as sure as my name 's Hobbinal.

sp.speaker: Oenone.
sp.p: I thank you, Sport: I'll study a requital.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Honour me with your fair hand, Nymph, that I may lead the way to all those pastimes which will follow.

sp.speaker: Oenone.
sp.p: The honour is to me, and I accept it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I'd laugh at that: no, Sport, I'll dance with thee my self.

sp.speaker: Oenone.
sp.p: Some other time by chance I may be at leisure.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: VVill you not? VVell, by this hand then I'll stand out, and laugh at every thing you do, right or wrong.

lg.l: Pshaw waw, this dancing is like my Mothers Mares trot:
Sport, shall I shew thee a Dance of my own fashion?

sp.speaker: Oenone.
sp.p: It cannot but content.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Nay, I know that: hark hither, Lads.

div.stage: Hobbinal and the shepherds dance a Morris.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: How like you this Sport?

sp.speaker: Oenone.
sp.p: Beyond Expression, Sport: I see your Vertues were concealed too long.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I, so they were; but I mean to shew them every day as fast as I can. But Sirrah, Sport, yonder's god Pan with a company of the bravest Satyrs that ever wore horns on their heads: come, Shepherds, let's go make them drunk, and saw off all their horns.

div.head: The Humour of Iohn Swabber.

argument.head: Argument needless,
argument.p: It being an ancient Farce, and generally known.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: HEreabout I am to meet this Hercules; and see, he's come.
sp.stage: Enter John Swabber armed with several ridiculous Weapons.
sp.p: Well, Iohn, I see you are prepar'd for murder: have mercy on the Barber, I say.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: No, I scorn it; I will have no mercy: he has made a whore of a wondrous honest woman; and a Cuckold of one, that for ought I know, might have been a Courtier. For which abominable deed, I scorn to shew my self a Christian; for I do mean to use him worse then a Jew would.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Nay, but consider, he's a man howe'er, and you can boast your self to be no more, although you have the spirit of a Giant: you have brought weapons here, as if you meant to kill him twenty times. Troth 'tis too much.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p:
If I bate him an Ace of forty, call me Coxcomb:
I will draw his teeth one by one, with an instrument called a pair of Tongs, then let him blood in the right vein, and bid the Devil take him at his own peril.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me prevail with thee to calm thy rage, and take acquaintance of this Gentleman, a worthy friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Do you long to be acquainted with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: By any means, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: 'Tis granted then: I'll toss a Can or a Pot with you as soon as I have dispatcht this bawdy Barber; would he were dead, that my business might be over.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What's your profession, Sir? and how may I call you?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I am a Sea-man, Sir; my name's Iohn Swabber:— an Officer of the Ship, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Nay, never cry for the matter.— But I had forgot this Barber all this while. Barber, come forth; or by the beard of my great Grandfather, I swear, I will so shashado, mashado, pashado, and carbinado thee, that thou shalt look like a Gallimafry all the days of thy Life. Come forth, I say.

sp.speaker: Cutbeard within.
sp.p: Why Neighbour Swabber, who provokes you thus? what do you mean? who has offended you?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: O Slave of all Slaves! who has offended me? why thou base, beastly, boisterous, Babylonian, bawdy-fac'd Barber, thou hast: thou hast made me fit to chew the cud with Oxen, climb the mountains with wild Goats, and keep company with none but Ram-headed people: for which I will tie thee up on the next Signe-post, and there thou shalt hang a twelvemoneth and a day alive, for an example to all such notable shavers; but if thou comest and submittest to my mercy, I will do thee the favour to let thee hang till thou be dead.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Francisco, hark:— I'll pawn my Life this fellow is a rank Coward: keep you his fury up, and I'll perswade the Barber to a greater vein of roaring then ere was practised by a suburb-Blade: I'll make him at the least seem valiant; fear not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do, if it be possible; I'll hold him in discourse.— But, Mr. Swabber, what think you if he does compound with you? will you be won to take an arm or two, or both his legs, and save his other members?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Pish, tell not me, 'tis neither his arms nor his legs that I stand upon; he has caused me to go in danger of my Life: for the other day I had an occasion to pass by a worshipful Gentleman's pack of Hounds, they no sooner looked upon my forehead, but they came at me in full cry; and I for fear left such a sent behind me, that they came after me as perfectly by it, as if I had been a Stagg; and if I had not got shelter of a house, without doubt I had been presented to some great man for Venison, and my Hanches had been baked by this time.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You were in danger there, I must confess.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: And the Butchers Dogs still take me for a Bull, and fetch such courses at me; and all this the Barber is the cause of.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I would revenge it: were I as you, he should not have a tool left him to work with.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: No, nor to play with neither: I will have an inch of every tool he has.— Barber, come forth, and let me kill thee upon fair terms; or else I mill enter thy house by force, pitch thee down the stairs, and send thee of an Errand headlong: and if thou dost submit to my mercy, I will shave thee to death with thy own Rasor: therefore take heed.— So, now let him come if he dare.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
VVell, now I see there is no hope to appease
him: blood must ensue, and death will take its course.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: VVith whom? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The Barber is preparing for the combat: he has took his pole to serve him for a lance, and one of his basons for a buckler, and vows to make you the wind-mill, whilst he plays Don Quixot against you furiously.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: A wind-mill!— I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You will not offer that, sure. VVhat afraid?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: VVould it not make any one tremble with the thought on't, first to be made a Cuckold, then a wind-mill? No, I will be gone, and come agen to kill him when I can finde him in a better humour.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Consider what you do; he'll call you Coward, proclaim you Cuckold still in every Ale-house; and what disgrace will that be?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I care not: 'tis better to be a Cuckold then a wind-mill. If he had meant to make a Fool, a Puppy, or an Asse of me, or any such Christian-like Creature, 'twere another matter: but to be made a wind-mill of, and never to be respected but when the wind blows, is not to be endured: therefore let him make wind-mills of my weapons, if he will; for my own part, I will defend my self with my heels.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, I have brought him to a better temper: he will come armed with nothing but a Razor; with which if he does suit your wezand-pipe, it will not be amiss to take it patiently.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Let him not spoile my drinking, and I care not: but hark you, if you should let him hurt me, I should be as angry as a Tygre.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: VVhere is this Slave that has provoked my rage to his destruction? I will swinge this Boor, then hang him up for Bacon in my chimney, and send him to be broyled for Pluto's breakfast.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: VVhy this is worse then to be made a wind-mill. Do you hear, Sir? if ever you had the fit of an Ague upon you, or ever knew the trembling of a Man troubled in Conscience, that would be loath to die till he had made even with all the world, consider me. Alas, Sir, I have my Rent to pay yet; and if I should be sent to Hell of an Errand, they'll like my company so well, I should never come back agen: pray perswade him to send me to Ierusalem, Iericho, or any of those places nearer hand.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: VVhy, canst not thou excuse thy self? where's thy brains?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Alas, my brains are fallen into my breeches; but if you'll stand between me and harm, I'll venture to reconcile my self to him.— Cut.— honest Cutbeard, didst not thou think I was in earnest all this while?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: VVhatere thou wert, thou shalt be nothing presently: Death waits for thee: come quickly, I command thee.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Sir, pray perswade Mr. Death to have patience for a matter of 40 or 50 years more: for I have a great deal of business to do in this world yet.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Shall I be dallied with? let me approach him: for all the intreaties of the world shall not preserve him past six minutes.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: One minute is past already,— and there's two.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Nay, prethee Cutbeard be more merciful.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Three— four— five.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: VVill no entreaty serve? Then take your course.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Six. O now I am gone.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: If he submit, he may live: let him know it.— Dost thou acknowledge thy own Cowardize, and my heroick Valour?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p:
O mighty Hercules, I confess my self a Pigmy,
and I will never think otherwise while I live, these Gentlemen be my witnesses.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: VVhy then all is well a gen..— Remember, Cutbeard.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I'll spice him, fear not.— Give me thy hand,

sp.speaker: Iack:
sp.p: Thus do I grasp thy friendship.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: He grasps my hand devillish hard tho.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I here pronounce thy wife to be a Venus.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: O rare! is my wife a Venus? That's more then ever I knew before: why then I will be her husband Cupid.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, Cupid was her Son.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that, he shall be her husband for once; and we two will get such abundance of young Cupids, that we'll make all the world in love with one another.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Since we are reconciled, know, honest Swabber, that I will make the whole world dote on thee: I'll wash thy face, and powder thee to the purpose, and shave thee if thou wilt too.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: No, by no means: I dare not venture my throat under thy Fingers: but for washing and powdring, that all the world may be in love with me, I am content.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Sit down then in this Chair, look on this powder, the snow is nothing to it; 'twill create such a complexion on thee, that no Art did ever set upon the proudest Lady.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: But hark you, Cutbeard, how shall I do to satisfie all the women that will follow me for kisses? if you make me too beautiful, my lips will be worn thread-bare before I can get home; and then Parnel my own dear wife, will have the least share of her own sweet husband.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: For that we'll take a course— wink, wink, good Iack; my Ball will search your eyes else.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: My eyes are honest, and fear no searching.

div.stage: Changes the Powder, and blacks his face all over.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Now I begin to sprucifie thy phisnomy:— This powder was extracted from the Phoenix, when she last burnt her self, and is indeed the quintessence of odours.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis as odious as ever I smelt, that is certain: good Cutbeard, let me have enough, I prethee.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Nay, I will spare no cost:— Judge, Gentlemen, is he not strangely altered?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Past belief: I would not that my Mistress saw him now, my hopes would soon be cooled then.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I think so: but I would have you to take notice, I will have nothing to do but with great personages; for I must not make my self common.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: VVhat this fellow will come to, no man knows yet; his fame no doubt will travel over all Countries, and I am fully resolved in my Opinion, the Queen of Mauritania will run mad for him.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: If she run as mad as a March-Hare, she gets not a bit: no, Parnel and my Neighbours shall have all.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Now if the Painters will draw Adonis our, let them come here for Copies. So, I have done.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Prethee Cutbeard, lend me a Looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: By no means: what, did you never hear of one Narcissus, how he pined away for love of his own shadow? No, go home, your house is hard by; let Parnel see you, and bless her self with wonder.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Honest Cutbeard, this Gentleman is a worthy friend of mine; prethee bestow some of the same powder upon his face.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, no, you shall be beautiful alone; 'tis best.

lg.l: Parnel, I come; and if thou beest not stupid,
Thou ' ●…t say Iack Swabber is a kin to Cupid.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
VVell, Cutbeard, thou hast drest him handsomely:
I would give a Crown that I were by when first he finds what beauty he is adorned withal.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: This day I am to meet with pretty Parnel; pray Heaven the Fool be absent when I come: some two hours hence, if you will meet me, Gentlemen, I will tell you how he takes his transmigration.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We will not fail. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: I wonder that my Barber stays thus long: can he neglect me thus? Well, I will fit him; for if he use me once agen thus basely, I will cashier him, and bestow my love upon some one more constant: forty to one but Swabber comes before him, and spoils all.
Who's this, in the name of blackness? the cloaths and walk of my dear husband, and I will lay my life he has got a Vizard on.— Nay pray now, indeed you'll fright me presently; take heed.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: She does not know me, that's excellent.— Parnel, believe it, I am flesh and blood; I would not have thee take me for a Goddess.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: A Goddess, quotha! a black one, if you be one: what hast thou got upon thy face, I prethee?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Do not look too wistfully upon me, Parnel; my beauty will put your eyes out if you do, and then I must be at the charge of a Dog and a Bell for you.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: A Dog and a fools head! pull off your Vizard.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Do not touch me, unless you make forty curtsies first. Come, kiss me, and thou wilt be out of thy wits presently.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Nay, then I see 'tis a trick put upon him; I'll fetch you a glass, you shall behold your beauty.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p:
Do, and I will venture to be in love with my self for once. How shall I require honest Cutbeard?
By this hand he shall have the honour to be Barber to all my Wenches.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Are you not wondrous fair? Look and admire your self.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: O Parnel, Parnel, I am gull'd most basely; I have not half so much beauty as a Chimney-sweeper: I will kill the Barber the first thing I do.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Was it the Barber used thee thus?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I▪ Parnel, 'twas he: I'll go fetch a company of my Fellow-saylors, drag him out, and hang him up at the main-Yard presently. Parnel, farewel: if I be apprehended for the death of Cutbeard, whatever thou dost, send me a clean shirt; for I shall have need on't.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Well, Cutbeard, I commend thee for this project; thou hast drest him handsomely: would thou wert here, I would kiss thee for the Jests sake.
Oh are you come, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I watch●… the time, my Parnel, and have found it: how does the Gull become his feathers? Ha!

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: As I would have him: Oh Cutbeard, this Kiss, and this, for the device.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Where is he, Parnel?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Why gone abroad in his new-fashion'd face, to fetch a gang of Saylors, who he vows shall hang thee up at the main-Yard, and shall use thee worse then the Prentices a Suburb-bawd on a Shrove-tuesday.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And those same Water-rats are devillish things: what a Slave was I to use him so?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: What canst thou fear when I am in thy presence? Away, you Milk-sop, hence from me, ●…ayant.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Nay, gentle Parnel, by this hand I will fight with a whole Army, if thou sayst the word: prethee be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Swab. within.
sp.p: Why Parnel, Parnel! here's thy own sweet husband; open the door, dear Wife.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: O me, my husband's come; what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Let me into the Well, if thou thinkest good; or hang me in the Chimney 'stead of Bacon.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Alas, that's full of hazard:— No device!

sp.speaker: Swab. within.
sp.p: Why huswife, huswife, must I wait half a day?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: My Peticoat's faln off; but I come presently.— Oh I have thought, come hither, put on this Biggin, I made it for my Childe that is at Nurse, and cram thy self into this Cradle here: there is no other way, therefore dispatch.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: O me! thou never thinkest upon my beard; that will betray all presently.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Take you no care, I'll make him to believe you were born with it; be quick, I say.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Necessity compels me: send me off of this brunt once, I'll hunt the smock no more.— Cover me close, good Parnel.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: So, keep you close; and when he prattles to you, sneeze in his face, and call him Dad; do you hear?

div.stage: Parnel lets him in. Enter Swabber?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Why you proud, peevish, petty, paltry Parnel, why did you make me stay so long?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: I made what haste I could, but the Childe cryed so.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: The Childe! what Childe? Have you got Bastards here?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Bastards? they are your own then: Simon's come home, the Boy I had a twelvemoneth since by you: he was born when you were at Sea.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Is he brought home? As I am an honest man I am glad on't. Let me see him, Parnel.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p:
Look here he is; the goodliest Boy, and even
as like thee, Iohn, as if thou hadst begot him all thy self.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Whoop! here's a Boy of a twelvemoneth old: if he grow but thus much this next year, he'll be able to fight with a Giant presently. But Parnel, he has got a great beard too, how comes that?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: VVhy he was born with it: many children are so; and 'tis a signe he will be a man betimes, a wise discreet one too.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Dad, dad, dad!

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis a wise Childe, I perceive that; for he calls me Dad at first sight. Good Parnel, fetch me some Milk for him; I will see him eat.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: He had Milk but just now: prethee, Iohn, be patient.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: You are a Fool, he has been starv'd at Nurse, and we must make him fat. Fetch some, I say.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: I will not, truly Iohn, you will spoile the Childe.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I saw some stand in the next room, I will fetch it my self, so I will.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: VVhat will you do? you must endure with patience; I mingled batter but just now for pancakes, and that he'll bring, as certain as I live.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I shall be cram'd to death: mercy upon me.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: He comes, lie close agen.

div.stage: Enter Swabber with a great Bowl of Batter, and a Ladle.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Dad, dad, dad!

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I, mine own Boy, here's Milk for thee, Simon.
sp.stage: Throws it in by Ladles f●…ll.
sp.p: Look, Parnel, look how greedily he eats it.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Now fie upon you, Iohn, you will choak the Childe.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I mean to make him grow as high as Pauls▪ and shew him for a wonder in Bartholomew Fayr. Fetch me some Milk, this is all gone.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: VVhat, do you think I will murder the poor Infant?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: By this hand I will go to the Milk-woman and fetch him a whole gallon.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Up quickly, and be gone; for when he comes, he will choak you without fail.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: A pox upon him, never was Childe fed thus. But what will you do now?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Do not you fear; I'll fetch my own Childe; 'tis at a Neighbours house, and say the Fairies have exchang'd it.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Send thee good luck: Farewel, sweet Parnel.

div.stage: Parnel fetches a little childe, and lays it in the cradle.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: So, if this Childe will serve him for a Simon, all will be well agen.
He comes.— Oh Iohn.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Come, give me Simon on my Lap; I will feed him till his Guts crack agen.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Alas, I went but in the next room, and in the mean time the Fairies have exchanged him; look what a little thing they have left in his place.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I will have none on't: go, fetch me Simon; and tell the Fairies I will indite them at the Sessions for this. Oh Simon, Simon, what is become of thee?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Nay, prethee take not on so.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: The goodliest Boy of his age that ever man saw. Pshaw, this has ne'er a beard: I will have none on't.

div.stage: Enter Francisco, Gerard, Cutbeard, Neighbours Wives.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: VVhy how now, Iack? what, in a passion? Ha, 'twas I that blackt thy face to day for mirth sake, and thou didst think it was Cutbeard.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I care not for my face; Simon is gone, that had a beard as big as Cutbeard's here: the Fairies have exchanged him, and look what a Chitty-face they have left in his room; a thing of nothing for him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, you must use this they have left with courtesie, for they will whip Simon every day in the week else: I know the nature of them.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: VVill they so? Nay, then I must make much on't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And now you must be friends with Cutbeard too.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: VVith all my heart; for I am angry with none but the Fairies now.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: VVe have brought Musick, and some Neighbours with us, and mean to have a Dance. Come, Iohn.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I can dance nothing but a melancholy Dance: for I am in a grievous dump for Simon still.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I warrant thee. Strike up there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: VVhy that's well done: no time is counted lost,
VVhere civil Mirth is gain'd with such small cost.

div.head: The Humours of Monsieur Galliard.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: He undertakes with the Foot, to correct State-matters, and teach the Subjects Reverence and Obedience to their King.

div.stage: Enter Sir William, Mr. Newman, Monsieur Galliard.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: ME be content to have de litel patience, and be my trot, me tel you, vat me have seen a to day, de fine sport in de Varle: me come into de Great Man to day, me make de reverence Alamode, come ill faut, and he make me de strange a Sir-reverence de tird time, dat ever you saw.

sp.speaker: Newm.
sp.p: Oh Monsieur, every Man has not the activity of your feet.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: By my fat, tis very estrange a ding, dat dey vil suffer a des Men to be neere a de King, a de Queene, de Prince, or de Princess, dey vil marra de understanding very mush.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why Monsieur, that lies at the other end.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Be gar you shall excuse a me, for de Conrtier Alamode dere de vit lie in de foot; be gar dere is no body can be Eiseman, dat does not make a de most excellent
reverence, dat is most certain, dat is de best ting in de hole Varle.

sp.speaker: Newm.
sp.p: But do you think Caesar, or most of the Emperours or Worthies of the world, studied the Liberal Science of the Foot, or puissant Toe?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: No; but be gar dat make dem dy all unfortunate: for if dey had tink but de reverence, dey might a live a great a vile.

sp.speaker: Newm.
sp.p: I confess the wisdome of it, Sir; but for the wit, do you think that lies there?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Dat be de best vit can be possible: for your vit, vat is your vit? Your vit is to break a de jeast; vel, look you now a me, me vil break a de jeast: Dat is like dat a me Lor, dat is like a de Knight, dat is like dat a de Jentilman: Ha, ha, ha! dere is now one, two, tre very good jeast datmake a me sick wide laugh; and be gar me vil make a de Page, de Lacquey, and all de foole in de Court, break ades very good jeast, very quickly, dat is nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To any purpose.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Be my trot me speak a to de King, and to de Queen to give me a Patten, dat none shall teach a de Aldermen to make a de Reverence but my self; and me vil undertake dat vit in one 12 a mont: but den dey must do noting else, dey shall make a de Reverence, vit de Aldermen in de Paris, and dance a Coran, a Cerebran, a Mountague, and dat vil be very brave.

sp.speaker: Newm.
sp.p: But what shall business do in the mean time, Monsieur?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Is not dis very great a business? Nay be gar, me vil undertake to de King, and to de Queene, to make a my Lor Maire, de Sheriffe and de Aldermen very fine a mask.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And to write it, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Aw, de write? dat is nothing alamode, your speesh two, tre yard long, pshaw? Give a me de quick a Spirit, de Fancie, de brave Scene, de varietie of de Antimask, de nimble a Foot, no matter de sense, begar it vole be de brave ting in de Christian varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: There is no question to be made.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And be my trot, if me have anoder Patten for de Councel learned in de Law, for to teash dem de reverence, dat vil be very great vark; but my diligence and skil in dat matre, have no despair to effect in time dis great benefit, and dat vil make a de Law flourish, and Englan a brave Englan begar.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: But what will you look for now for your pains, Monsieur? that is considerable.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Begar me look for very mush; for 'tis mush pain, and 'tis brave ting: beside, me look for a Statur of de brass in de Palace-yard, ven me go out of dis varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You will deserve it as a rare Patriot. But what manner of Reverence would you have the Lawyers to imitate? you must consider their Gravity.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Observe a me.

sp.speaker: Newman.
sp.p: Such a Reverence under your favour would not become.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Begar you no understand a de matre, vere is your brain? dere is noting in de varle like a dat motion, for de Jentilman, and for de Jentilvoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, by your leave, Sir, there is somthing else that is as good for them.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
I vil tell you now, begar, here is a de Kinsman dat is a me, and he live here very mush time, before he come, dey vent in vid deire Toes, and hold deire Cloak in Stadere, and de Hat so. Fie, a la diable! and now dey valk vid deire Toes out for brave Genty, you call dat a de splay-foot: but me vonder dat de Lady no
come, begar me no use to dis patience, and de vait: pray tell you Madam dat me have autre business vid de Lor, and de autre Lady have de use of my foot begar.

sp.speaker: Newm.
sp.p: Oh Monsieur, by no means: Sir William, let us prevail.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: 'Tis no good you hold a me begar: me no stay two minutes to save a your soul, dat is de resolution of de Cavalier de France

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Would any man believe there should be so much folly in this Cubit-square?

sp.speaker: Newm.
sp.p: Do you think he is a French Dancer? Let that answer you.

div.stage: Enter Mris. Lucie, Galliard, and Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Mris. Lucie.
sp.p: Monsieur Galliard, my Lady expects you.

sp.speaker: Galliard.
sp.p: Begar me no lik adat reverence, me vill change a dat.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: 'Tis the French Fashion, as you taught me, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Ouy, 'tis de French Fashion, but de French Fashion is always to change, and dis reverence displease a me very mush, because you go back, back vid your buttock, as if some vod take you by dat, to vat me vill give a no name.

sp.speaker: Simpl.
sp.p: Sweet Mris. Lucy.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Dat de reverence is no good of de man, me must change dat too: be me trot me doubt dat dis great business vill almost break a my brain, dis great work, and before a Masque of de King and de Queen. Me can eat a no meat, no drink, no sleep, and me grow so very a lean vid de Contemplation, a so much be my trot de Privie Councel is no so mush troubled as me be vid dis: Oh te Diable! deirs is noting, dey fit all de vile dey do
deir business: me bissey bote head and de foot cap a pie, in de French tune, and dat is great matre begar.

sp.speaker: Mris. Lucy.
sp.p: You esteem it highly, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Me tell you, and me tell you no tale, 'Tis great matre to make a de Lor, to make a de
