Lady, to make a de Jentilman, to make a de Jentilwoman, and de autre man to dance, and to make a de boon reverence, for begar dat vil make a de King de great King in de Varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How can that be, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Me tell you, ven dey are so bissey to learn a de dance, dey vill never tinke of de Rebellion, and den de reverence is obedience to Monarchy, and begar obedience is ale de ting in de Varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: But what Musick would you govern the people by?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Begar by de best French Fiddles can be got.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What think you of an Irish Harp, a State-Organ, or a Passionate voice to a Lovers Lute?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Des dull tings make a de men melancholique, and den dey tinke on de Devil, and de Treason, and do any ting dat is no good; but begar des French Fiddles do fiddle all des tings out of deit head, vid such a jerk as ma ●…oy make a dem so phantasticall, and make a dem as good subject as any is in de France, begar. Here be one of my Colliers, Monsieur Simpleton, Say you no dat de French Fiddle make a de brave Government in a de Varle?

sp.speaker: Simpleton.
sp.p: I say any thing becomes a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Observe you dat? he have been but two tree mont, and he say any ting dat is brave. He have de grand understanding in de foot. Tell a me ven you hear a de littel fiddel vat is your tink? is your head no free from de Treason, and de plot of de Rebel as your leg? begar you no stand upon de ground for joy of de
Coran, de Cerebran, de Marquess, de Montague, ha! Me be your humble servant Madam.
and stay one two tree hours.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am now ready for you Monsieur. Come Lucy, the practice of the last he taught us.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Wat Antique be dis?

sp.speaker: Simpleton.
sp.p: Monsieur, ask that May-pole and he can dance.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Plait il Monsieur, a la Galliard de Coran, la Princess, le Buckingham, heigh?

sp.speaker: Manley.
sp.p: Put up your rosin and your Cats-guts presently, and be gone, or I shall find a grave for you in the pocket of my sleeve, and this shall be your winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Me no play dat lesson: Pocket de sleeve? dat is no tune de France: pocket, le grand pock— Pardonne moy Monsieur: Me put up my offers to strike him Fiddel and be gone. Adieu Madam, Serviteur jentilhommes. Pocket de sleeve?

div.head: The LANDLADY.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: A Gentleman by accident takes a child and brings it to his Lodging; his friend afterward happens to meet with a Lady, the mother of the child (unknown) and brings her to the Lodging, &c.

div.stage: Enter Don Iohn and his Landlady with a child.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: NAy son,
If this be your regard.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Good Mother.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Good me no goods; your Cousin and your self are welcome to me whilest you bear your selves like honest and true Gentlemen. Bring hither to my house, that hath ever been reputed a Gentlewoman of a decent and fair carriage, and so have behaved my self?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I know ye have.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Bring hither, as I say, to make my house stink in my neighbors nostrils, your devices, your Brats got out of Alligant and broken Oaths? your linsey work, your hasty puddings? I foster up your filch'd iniquities? y'are deceived in me, for I am none of those receivers.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Have I not sworn unto you 'tis none of mine, and shew'd you how I found it?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Ye found an easie fool that let you get it: she had better have worn Posterons.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Will ye hear me?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Oaths? what do you care for oaths to gain your ends, when you are high and pamper'd? what Saint know ye? or what Religion, but your purpos'd lewdness, is to be looked for of ye? Nay, I will tell ye, ye will then swear like accus'd Cut-purses? as far off truth too: and lie beyond all Faulconers. I'm sick to see this dealing.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, Mother.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Nay, I am very sick.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Anthony.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Bring down the bottle of Canary wine.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Exceeding sick, Heaven help me.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I must ev'n make her drunk. Nay, gentle mother.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Now fie upon ye.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Here mother, take a good round draught, 'twill purge spleen from your spirits: deeper, mother.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: I, I, son; you imagine this will mend all.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: All ifaith, mother.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: I confess this wine will do his part.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I'll pledge you.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: But son Iohn, I know your meaning.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Mother, touch it once more, alas you look not well; take a round draught, it warms the blood well, and restores the colour, and then we'll talk at large.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: A civil Gentleman! a stranger! one that should weigh his fair name! Oh, a stitch.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: There's nothing better for a stitch: good mother make no spare of it, as you love your health: Mince not the matter.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p:
As I said, a Gentleman lodge in my house!
now heaven's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I looked for this.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Where's the infant? come, let's see your workmanship.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: None of mine, mother; but there 'tis, and a lusty one.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Heaven bless thee, thou hadst a hasty making; but the best is, 'tis many a good mans fortune. As I live, your own eys, Seignior, and the nether lip as like ye, as if ye had spit it.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Bless me, what things are these!

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I thought my labour was not all lost; 'tis gold, and these are jewels, both rich, and right I hope.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Well, well, son Iohn, I see you are a woodman, and can chuse your Deer though it be i'ch' dark; all your discretion is not yet loft, this was well clapt aboard here: I am with you now, when, as they say, your pleasure comes with profit, when you must needs do where ye may be done to; 'tis a wisdom becomes a young man well. Be sure of one thing, loose not your labour and your time together, it seasons of a fool. Son, time is pretious, work wary whilst ye have it. Since ye must traffique sometimes this slippery way, take sure hold, Seignior, trade with no broken Merchants: make your lading as you would make your rest, adventurously, and with advantage ever.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: All this time, mother, the child wants looking to, meat and Nurse.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Now blessing o'thy care, it shall have all, and instantly; I'l seek a Nurse my self, son; 'tis a sweet child: Ah my young Spaniard, take you no farther care sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
Yes, of these jewels I must, by your leave mother: these are yours, to make your care the stronger;
for the rest I'll find a master; the gold for bringing up on't, I freely render to your charge.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: No more words, nor no more children (good son) as you love me, this may do well.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I shall observe your Morals.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Come, ye do know—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I do not, by this hand Mistress, but I suspect.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: That if eggs continue at this price, women will ne'r be sav'd by their good works.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: I will know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ye shall, any thing lies in my power. The Duke of Lorrain is now 7000 strong: I heard it of a Fish-wife, a woman of fine knowledge.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Sirrah, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: The Popes Buls are broken loose too, and 'tis suspected they shall be baited in England.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No, 'tis not so well neither.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: But I say to you, Who is it keeps your Master companie?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I say to you, Don Iohn.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: I say to you, what woman?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I say so too.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: I say again, I will know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I say 'tis fit you should.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: And I tell thee he has a woman here.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And I tell thee, 'tis then the better for him.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: You are no Baud now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Would I were able to be call'd unto it. A worshipful Vocation for my Elders; for as I understand, i●… is a place fitting my betters far.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Was ever Gentlewoman so frumpt off with a Fool? Well, sawcie sirrah, I will know who it is, and for what purpose. I pay the rent, and I will know how my house comes by these inflammations. If this geer hold, best hang a sign-post up, to tell the Seigniors, here you may have Lewdness at libertie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: 'Twould be a great ease to your age.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How now? why what's the matter Landlady?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: What's the matter? ye use me decently among ye, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who has abus'd her? you sir?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Ods my witness, I will not be thus treated, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I gave her no ill language.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Thou liest lewdly, thou tookst me up at every word I spoke, as I had been a Mawkin, a Flutt-Gillian: And thou thinkst, because thōu canst write and read, our noses must be under thee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dare you, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: She raves of Wenches, and I know not what, Sir.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Go to, thou knowest too-well, thou wicked Varlet.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: As I live Sir, she is ever thus till dinner.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Get you in.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: By this hand I'll break your posset-pan.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Then by this hood I'll lock the meat up.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Now your grief, what is't? for I can ghess.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Ye may with shame enough, if there were shame amongst ye; nothing thought on but how you may abuse my house: not satisfi'd with bringing home your Bastards to undo me, but you must drill your Whores here too? My patience (because I beat and bear, and carry all, and as they say am willing to groan under) must be your Make-sport now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No more of these words, nor no more murmurings, Lady: for you know that I know something. I did suspect your anger; but turn it presently, and handsomely, and bear your self discreet to this woman, for such a one there is indeed.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: 'Tis well, son.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Leaving your Devils Matins, and your Melancholies, or we shall leave our lodgings.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: You have much need to use these vagrant ways, and to much profit: ye had that might content you (at home, within your selves too) right good, Gentlemen, wholsom, and ye said handsome. But you gallants, boast that I was to believe you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Leave your suspition: for as I live, there's no such thing.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Mine honour; and 'twere not for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Come, your honour, your house, and you too, if you dare believe me, are well enough. Sleek up your self, leave crying.

sp.speaker: Don Iohn.
sp.p: Worshipful Lady, how does thy velvet scabbard? by this hand thou look'st most amiably; now could I willingly, and 'twere not for abusing thy Geneva-Print there, venture my body with thee.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: You will leave this roguery when you come to my years.

sp.speaker: Don Ioh.
sp.p: By this light, thou art not above fifteen yet, a meer girl; thou hast not half thy teeth—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Prithee Iohn let her alone, she has been vext already: she'll grow stark mad.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I would see her mad. An old mad woman is like a Millers Mare troubled with tooth-ach. She'll make the rarest faces!

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p:
VVell Don Iohn, there will be times again, when O good mother, what's good for a Carnositie in
the Bladder? O the green water, mother.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Doting take ye, do you remember that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She has paid you now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Clarie, sweet mother, Clarie.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Are ye satisfied?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: I'll never whore again, never give Petticoats and VVastcoats at five pounds apiece; good mother, quickly mother. Now mock on, son.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: A devil grind your old chaps.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: By this hand, VVench, I'll give thee a new hood for this. Has she met with your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Touch-wood take her, she's a rare costly mother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have told you all I can; to me you seem a worthy woman, one of those are seldom found in our sex, VVise, and Vertuous. Direct me, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Ye say well, Lady, and hold to that point; for in these businesses a womans counsel that conceives the matter, Do ye mark me, that conceives the matter, Lady, is worth ten mens engagements: she knows something, and out of that, can work like wax; when men are giddy-headed, either out of wine, or a more drunkenness, vain ostentation, discovering all: there is no more keep in 'um, then hold upon an Eels tail; nay, 'tis held fashion to defame now all they can.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I, but these Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p:
Do not you trust to that: these Gentlemen are as all other Gentlemen, of the same Barrel; I, and the self-same Pickle. Be it granted they have used ye with respect and fair behaviour yet since ye came: do you know what must follow? They are Spaniards, Lady, Gennets of high mettle: Things that will thrash the
Devil or his Dam, let 'em appear but cloven.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now Heaven bless me!

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Mad Colts will court the VVind: I know 'em, Lady, to the least hair they have; and I tell you, old as I am, let but the pint-pot bless'em, they'll offer to my years.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How!—

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Such rude Gambols—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To you?—

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: I, and so handle me, that oft I am forced to fight of all four for my safetie: There's the younger, Don John, the arrantest Jack in all this Citie. The other, Time has blasted, yet he will stoop, if not ore-flown, and freely on the Quarrie: Has been a Dragon in his days. But Tarmont, Don Jenkin is the Devil himself; the Dog-days the most incomprehensible VVhoremaster, twentie a night is nothing; Beggers, Broom-women, and those so miserable, they look like famine, are all sweet Ladies in his drink.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He's a handsom Gentleman, pitie he should be master of such follies.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: He's ne'r without a noise of Syrrenges in's pocket, those proclaim him, Birding-pills, VVaters to cool his Conscience, in small Viols; with thousand such sufficient emblems. The truth is, whose Chastitie he chops upon, he cares not. He flies at all; Bastards upon my Conscience he has in making, multitudes; The last night he brought home one, I pitie her that bore it, but we are all weak Vessels: some rich woman, (for VVise I dare not call her) was the mother, for it was hung with jewels, the bearing-cloth no less then crimson-Velvet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: VVas it a boy too?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: A brave boy, deliberation and judgement shew'd in's begetting; as I'll say for him, he's as well pac'd for that sport.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: May I see it?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: You shall see it: but what do ye think of these men now you know 'em, and of the cause I told ye of? I but tell you for your own good, and as you will find it, Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am advised.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: No more words then; do that, and instantly.

sp.speaker: Don Joh.
sp.p: I'll fit you for your frumps: she that's wise leaps at occasion first; the rest pay for it.

div.head: The TESTY LORD.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: He is imployd near the King, in which office he exerciseth his Passion, and is as crosly dealt withall by another Lord.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: DIagoras, look to the doors better for shame, you let in all the world, and anon the King will rail at me: by Jove, the King will have the Shew i'th ' Court.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: Why do you swear so, my Lord? you know he'll have it here.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: By this light, if he be wise he will not.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: And if he will not be wise, you are forsworn.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: One may sweat his heart out with swearing, and get thanks on no side; I'll be gone, look to't who will.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: My Lord, I will never keep 'em out: pray stay, your looks will terrifie 'em.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: My looks terrifie 'em, you Coxcombly Ass you? I'll be judg'd by all the companie whether thou hast not a worse face then I.—

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: I mean, because they know you and your office.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Office? I would I could put it off. I am sure I sweat quite through my office: serve that will.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: He's so humorous,— hark, hark; there, there, so, so, cuds, cuds, what now?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Let him not in.

sp.speaker: Diag
sp.p: O my Lord, he must: is your
Lady plac'd?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I thank you. My Lord Calianax, well met; your causless hate to me I hope is buried.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Who plac'd the Lady there, so near the presence of the King?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: My Lord, she must not sit there.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: The place is kept for a woman of more worth.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: More worth then she? it mis-becomes your age and place to be so womanish; forbear: what you have spoke, I am content to think the Palsie shook your tongue to.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Why 'tis well if I stand here to place mens Wenches?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I shall forget this place, thy age, and through all, cut that poor sickly VVeek thou hast to live, away from thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay, I know you can fight for your VVhore.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Bate the King, and he be flesh and blood, he lies that saies it: thy mother at fifteen was black and sinful to her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I, you may say your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: VVhat vild injurie has stirred my worthy friend, who is as slow to fight with words as he is quick of hand?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: That heap of age which I should reverence if it were temperate; but testie years are most contemptible.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Good Sir forbear.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: There is just such another as your self.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: He will wrong you or me, or any man, and talk as if he had no life to lose.

div.stage: Enter Calianax to Aspatia, and two Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: How now huswifes? what, at your ease? is this a time to sit still? Up, you young lazie whores, up, or I'll swinge you.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: You'll lie down shortly; Get you in and work: what, are you grown so restie? you want ears; we shall have some of the Court-boys do that office.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: My Lord, we do no more then we are charg'd; it is the Ladies pleasure we be thus in grief: she is forsaken.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
There's a rogue too, a young dissembling slave; well, get you in, I'll have a bout with that boy, 'tis high time now to be valiant. I confess my youth was never prone that way: what, made an Ass? a Court-Stale? VVell, I will be valiant, and beat some dozen of these whelps, I will: and there's another of 'em, a trim cheating Souldier, I'll mawl that Rascal; has out▪ brav'd me
twice, but now I thank the gods I am valiant: Go, get you in, I'll take a course with all.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: O Melantius, my daughter will die.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Trust me, I am sorry; would thou hadst ta'n her room.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Thou art a Slave, a Cut-throat Slave, a bloody treacherous Slave.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Take heed, old Man, thou wilt be heard to rave, and lose thine offices.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I am valiant grown at all these years, and thou art but a Slave.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Leave: some companie will come, and I respect thy years, not thee so much, that I could wish to laugh at thee alone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I'll spoil your mirth, I mean to fight with thee; there lie my Cloak, this was my fathers sword, and he durst fight; are you prepar'd?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: VVhy? wilt thou dote thy self out of thy life? hence, get thee to bed, have careful looking to, and eat warm things, and trouble not me; my head is full of thoughts more weightie then thy life or death can be.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: You have a name in VVar, when you stand safe amongst a multitude; but I will trie what you dare do unto a weak old Man in single fight; you'll ground I fear. Come, draw.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I will not draw, unless thou pull'st thy death upon thee with a stroke: there's no one blow that thou canst give, hath strength enough to kill me. Tempt me not so far then; the power of earth shall not redeem thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
I must let him alone, he's stout and able; and to say the truth, however I may set a face and talk, I am
not valiant. VVhen I was a youth, I kept my credit with a testie trick I had amongst Cowards, but durst never fight.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I will not promise you to preserve your life if you do stay.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I would give half my land that I durst fight with that proud man a little: if I had men to hold, I would beat him till he ask me mercie.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Sir, will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I dare not stay, but I will go home and beat my servants all over for this.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: This old Man haunts me; but the distracted carriage of mine Amintor takes deeply on me, I will find the cause: I fear his Conscience cries, he wrong'd Aspatia.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Good my Lord, forget your spleen to me; I never wrong'd you, but would have peace with every man.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: 'Tis well: if I durst fight, your tongue would lie at quiet.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Y'are touchie without cause.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Do, mock me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: By mine honour.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Honour? where is't?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: See what stairs you make into your hatred, to my love and freedome to you.— I come with resolution to obtain a suit of you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: A suit of me? 'tis very like it should be granted, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, go not hence: 'Tis this, You have the keeping of the Fort, and I would wish you, by the love you ought to bear unto me, to deliver it into my hands.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I am in hope that thou art mad, to talk to me thus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: But there is a reason to move you to it. I would kill the King, that wrong'd you and your daughter.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Out Traitour!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, but stay; I cannot scape, the deed once done, without I have this Fort.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: And should I help thee? Now thy treacherous mind betraies it self.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come, delay me not, give me a sudden answer, or already thy last is spoke: refuse not offer'd love when it comes clad in secrets.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: If I say I will not, he will kill me; I do see it writ in his looks: and should I say I will, he'll run and tell the King. I do not shun your friendship, dear Melantius, but this cause is weightie, give me but an hour to think.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Take it,— I know this goes unto the King, but I am arm'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Methinks I feel my self but twentie again, this fighting Fool wants policie. I shall revenge my Girl, and make her red again. I pray my legs will last that pace that I will carry, I shall want breath before I finde the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It sounds incredible.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Yes, so does every thing I say, of late.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Not so, Calianax.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Yes, I should sit mute, whilst a rogue with strong arms cuts your throat.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well, I will trie him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Why, if it be alie, mine ears are false, for I'll be sworn I heard it. Old men are good for nothing; you
were best to put me to death for hearing, and free him for meaning of it; you would have trusted me once, but the time is altered.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And will still, where I may do it with Justice to the world. You have no witness?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Yes, my self.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No more, I mean, there were that heard it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: How, no more? why am not I enough to hang a thousand Rogues?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But so you may hang honest men too, if you please.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I may, 'tis like I will do so; there are a hundred will swear it for a need too, if I say it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Such witnesses we need not.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: And 'tis hard if my word cannot hang a boisterous Knave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Enough: if he should desire the Combat of you, 'tis not in the power of all our Laws to hinder it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Why, if you do think 'tis fit an old Man and a Counsellour to fight for what he saies, then you may grant it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Give me a bowl of wine: Melantius, I am now considering how easie 'twere for any man to trust to poison one of us in such a bowl.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I think it were not hard, Sir, for a Knave.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Such as you are.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Have you thought of this, Calianax?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Yes marry have I.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: And what's your resolution?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Ye shall have it soundly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Yet I wonder much of the strange desperation of these men; he could not escape that did it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Were he known, unpossible.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It would be known, Melantius; I should think no man could kill me and scape clear, but that old Man.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: But I! Heaven bless me, I? should I, my Liege?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I do not think thou wouldst, but yet thou mightst, for thou hast in thy hands the means to scape, by keeping of the Fort; he has, Melantius, and he has kept it well.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: From Cobwebs, Sir, 'tis clean swept.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I shall be sure of your good word; but I have kept it safe from such as you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Melantius, to shew you my ears are every where, You meant to kill me, and get the Fort to scape.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You preserve a race of idle people here about you, Eaters, and Talkers, to defame mens worths; Give me a pardon (for you ought to do't) to kill him that spake this.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I, that will be th'end of all; then I am fairly paid for all my care and service.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: That old Man that calls me enemie, and of whom I (thought I will never match my hate so low) have no good thought, would yet I think excuse me, and swear he thought me wrong'd in this.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Who I? thou shameless fellow, didst thou not speak to me of it thy self?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O, then it came from him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: From me? who should it come from, but from me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, I believe your malice is enough, but I ha▪ lost my anger. Sir, I hope you are well satisfied.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Melantius, I held it great injustice to believe thine enemie, and did not; if I did, I do not: let that satisfie.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: A few fine words have overcome my truth. Ah, th'art a Villain.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Why thou wilt let me have the Fort, Dotard; I will disgrace thee thus for ever: there shall no credit lie upon thy words: think better, and believe it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: My Liege, he's at me now again to do it; speak, deny it if thou canst? Example him whilst he's hot, for he'll cool again, he will forswear it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This is Lunacy I hope, Melantius?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: He has lost himself much: and though he call me Foe, I pitie him; for it becomes both you and me too, to forgive distraction: Pardon him as I do.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I'll not speak for thee, for all thy cunning; if you will be safe, chop off his head, for there was never known so impudent a Rascal.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Some that love him, get him to bed.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Calianax, the King believes you; come, you shall go home and rest, you ha' done well; you'll give it up when I have us'd you thus a Moneth I hope.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Now, now, 'tis plain Sir, he does move me still; he saies, he knows I will give him up the Fort, when he has us'd me thus this Moneth; I am mad, am I not still?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I shall be mad indeed, if you do thus; why would you trust a sturdy fellow there, (that has no vertue in him, all's in's sword) before me? do but take his weapons away from him, and he's an Ass, and I am a very Fool, both with him and without him, as you use me.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis well, Calianax; but if you use this once again, I shall intreat some other to see your offices be well discharged. Good Calianax sleep soundly, it will bring thee to thy self.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes. Manent Mel. and Cal.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Sleep soundly! I sleep soundly now, I hope, I could not be thus else! How dar'st thou stay alone with
me, knowing how thou hast us'd me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You cannot blast me with your tongue, and that's the strongest part you have about you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I do look for some great punishment for this, for I begin to forget all my hate, and take't unkindly that mine enemie should use me so extraordinarily scurvily.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I shall melt too, if you begin to take unkindness; I never meant you hurt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Thou'lt anger me again; thou wretched rogue, meant me no hurt? disgrace me with the King, lose all my offices? this is no hurt, is it? I prithee what dost thou call hurt?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: To poison me because they love me not; to call the credit of Mens wives in question, to murder children betwixt me and land; this is all hurt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: All this thou thinkst is sport, for mine is worse; but use thy will with me, for betwixt grief and anger I could crie.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Be wise then, and be safe; thou mayest revenge.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I o'th' King? I would revenge o'thee.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: That you must plot your self.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I am a fine Plotter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: The short is, I will hold thee with the King in this perplexitie, till peevishness, and thy disgrace hath laid thee in the grave. But if thou wilt deliver up the Fort, I'll take thy trembling body in my arms, and bear thee over dangers; thou shalt hold thy wonted state.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: If I should tell the King, canst thou deny't again?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Trie and believe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay, then thou canst bring any thing about; thou shalt have the Fort.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Why well, here let our hate be buried.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Nay, I do not love thee yet; I cannot well endure
to look on thee. And if I thought it were a curtesie, thou shouldst not have it; but I am disgrac'd, my offices are to be ta'n away. And if I did but hold this Fort a day, I do believe the King would take it from me, and give it thee, things are so strangely carried; Ne'r thank me for't: but yet the King shall know there was some such thing in't I told him of, and that I was an honest man.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: He'll buy that knowledge very dearly. What news with thee?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: This were a night indeed to do it in.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Go, Diphilus, and take from this good man, my worthy friend, the Fort, he'll give it thee.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Ha'you got that too?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Art thou of the same breed? canst thou deny this to the King too?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: With a confidence as great as his.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Faith like enough.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Away, and use him kindly.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Touch not me, I hate the whole strain: if thon follow me a great way off, I'll give thee up the Fort, and hang your selves.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Diphil.
sp.p: He's finely wrought.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Under the notion of his knowledge in Chymistrie, he cheats a Grocer and a Precisian.

sp.speaker: Subtle.
sp.p: COme in, What is your name, say you, Abel Drugger?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Umh. Free of the Grocers?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: I, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Well,— Your business, Abel?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: This, an't please your worship; I am a young beginner, and am building of a new Shop, an't please your Worship, just at corner of a street, (here's the plat on't) and I would know by Art, Sir, of your Worship, which way I should make my door, by Necromancie, and where my Shelves, and which should be for Boxes, and which for Pots. I would be glad to thrive, Sir: and I was wisht to your Worship, by a Gentleman, one Captain Face, that saies you know mens Planets, and their good Angels and their bad.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I do, if I do see 'em.—

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: VVhat! my honest Abel? thou art well met here.

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p:
Troth Sir, I was speaking just as your VVorship
came here, of your VVorship: I pray you speak for me to Master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: He shall do any thing. Doctor, do you hear? this is my friend, Abel, an honest fellow; he lets me have good Tobacco, and he does not sophisticate it with Sack-lees, or Oyl, nor washes it in Muscadel, and Grains, nor buries it in Gravel, under ground, wrapt up in greasie leather, or pist clouts, but keeps it in fine Lilie-pots, that opened, smell like Conserve of Roses, or French Beans. He has his Maple block, his silver tongs, VVinchester pipes, and fire of Juniper. A neat, spruce-honest fellow, and no Goldsmith.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: He is a fortunate fellow, that I am sure on.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Already Sir, Ha you found it? Lo thee Abel.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: And in right way toward riches.—

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: This Summer, he will be of the clothing of his Companie: and next Spring called to the Scarlet, spend what he can.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: What, and so little beard!

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Sir, you must think he may have a receit to make hair come: But he'll be wise, preserve his youth, and fine for't: his fortune looks for him another way.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: 'Slid Doctor, how canst thou know this so soon? I am amus'd at that!

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: By a rule, Captain, in Metaposcopy, which I do work by, a certain Star i'th' forehead, which you see not. Your Chest-nut, or your Olive-colour'd face does never fail; and your long ear doth promise. I knew't by certain spots too, in his teeth, and on the nail of his Mercurial finger.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Which finger's that?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: This little finger. Look, you were born upon a VVednesday?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: The thumb, in Chiromancie, we give Venus, the fore-finger to Iove, the midst to Saturn, the ring to Sol, the least to Mercury, who was the Lord, Sir, of this Horoscope; his House of Life being Libra, which foreshew'd he should be a Merchant, and should trade with balance.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: VVhy this is strange, is't not, honest Nab?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: There is a Ship now coming from Ormus, that shall yeild him such a commoditie of Drugs.— This is the VVest, and this the South?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: And those are your two sides?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Make me your Door then South, your broad-side VVest. And on the East-side of your Shop, aloft, write Mathlai, Tarmiel, and Baraborat; upon the North part, Rael, Velel, Thiel: they are the names of those Mercurial Spirits that do fright Flies from Boxes.

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: And beneath your threshold, bury me a Loadstone to draw in Gallants that wear Spurs: the rest they'll seem to follow.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: That's a Secret, Nab!

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: And on your Stall, a Puppet with a Vice, and a Court-fucus to call Citie-Dames. You shall deal much with Minerals.

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Sir, I have, at home, already—

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I, I know you have Arsnike, Vitriol, Sal-tartre, Argaile, Alkaly, Cinoper; I know all. This fellow, Captain, will come, in time, to be a great Distiller, and give a say, (I will not say directly, but very fair) at the Philosophers Stone.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: VVhy how now, Abel? is this true?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Good Captain, what must I give him?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Nay, I'll not counsel thee; thou hear'st what wealth (he saies, Spend what thou canst) th'art like to come to.

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: I would give him a Crown.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: A Crown! and toward such a Fortune! Hear, thou shalt rather give him thy Shop. No gold about thee?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Yes, I have a Portague, I have kept this half year.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Out on thee, Nab! 'Slight, there was such an offer— Shalt keep't no longer, I'll giv't him for thee. Doctor, Nab praies your Worship to drink this, and he will appear more grateful, as your skill does raise him in this VVorld.

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: I would intreat another favour of his VVorship.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: VVhat is't, Nab?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: But to look over, Sir, my Almanack, and cross out my ill days; that I may neither bargain, nor trust upon them.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: That he shall, Nab.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: And a direction for his Shelves.

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: And one thing more, Sir.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: VVhat is it, Nab?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: A Sign, Sir.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: I, a good luckie one, a thriving Sign, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I was devising now.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: ('Slight, Do not say so, he must give you more.) What say you to his Constellation, Doctor, the Balance?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
No, that way is stale, and common. A Townsman born in Taurus, gives the Bull, or the Bulls head; in Aries, the Ram. A poor device: No, I will have his Name formed in some mystick Character; whose radii striking the senses of the Passers-by, shall, by a vertual
influence, breed affections that may result upon the partie owns it. As thus,—

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Nab, hast no more gold?

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Not here, Sir, I protest.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: He first shall have A Bel, that's Abel; and one standing by, whose name is Dee, in a rugg Gown; there's D and Rugg, that's Drugg; and right anenst him, a Dog snarling Er, there's Drugger, Abel Drugger; that's his Sign. And here's now Mysterie and Hieroglyphick.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Abel, thou art made.

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Sir, I do thank his Worship.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Six o'thy legs more will not do it, Nab. He has brought you a pipe of Tobacco, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Drug.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: It seems to be good Tobacco; what is't an ounce?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: He'll send you a pound or two, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: O no!

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: He will do't. It is the goodest soul! Abel, about it; thou shalt know more anon: away, be gone.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Keep aloof off, yonder's another Chapman: observe my call.
Where is my drudge?—

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Take away the Recipient, and rectifie the Menstrue from the Phlegma; then pour it o'the Sol, in the Cucurbite, and let 'em macerate together.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Yes Sir. And save the ground?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: No, Terra damnata must not have entrance in the work. Who are you?

sp.speaker: Ananias.
sp.p: A faithful Brother, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: What's that? a Lullianist? a Ripley? filius artis? Can you sublime, and dulcifie? calcine? Know you the Sapor pontick? Sapor styptick? or what is homogene, or heterogene?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: I understand no heathen language, truly.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Heathen, you Knipper-Doling? is ars sacra, or Chrysopoeia, or Spagyrica, or the Pamphysick, or Panarchick knowledge, a Heathen language?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: Heathen Greek, I take it.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: How! Heathen Greek?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: All's Heathen but the Hebrew.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Sirrah, my Varlet, Stand you forth, and speak to him like a Philosopher: Answer i'th' language: Name the Vexations, and the Martyrizations of Metals in the Work.

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Sir, Putrefaction, Solution, Ablution, Sublimation, Cohobation, Calcination, Ceration, and Fixation.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: This is Heathen Greek to you now? And when comes Vivification?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: After Mortification.

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: What's Cohobation?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: 'Tis the pouring on your aqua regis, and then drawing him off, to the trine circle of the seven sphears.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: VVhat's the proper passion of Metals?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Malleation.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: VVhat's your Ultimum supplicium auri?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: Antimonium.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: This is Heathen Greek to you? And what's your Mercury?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: A very fugitive, he will be gone, Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: How know you him?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: By his Viscositie, his Oleositie, and his Suscitabilitie.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: How do you sublime him?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: VVith the Calce of Egg-shels, white Marble, halk.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Your Magisterium, now, what's that?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p:
Shifting, Sir, your elements, dry into cold, cold
into moist, moist into hot, hot into drie.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: This is Heathen Greek to you still? Your Lapis Philosophicus?

sp.speaker: Face.
sp.p: 'Tis a Stone, and not a Stone; a spirit, a soul, and body: which if you do dissolve, it is dissolved; if you coagulate, it is coagulated; if you make it to flie, it flieth.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Enough: this is Heathen Greek to you? what are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: Please you, a servant of the exile Brethren, that deal with VVidows and with Orphans goods, and make a just account unto the Saints; a Deacon.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: O you are sent from Mr. Wholsome your Teacher?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: From Tribulation Wholsome, our very zealous Pastor.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Good. I have some Orphans goods to come here.

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: Of what kinde, Sir?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Pewter, and Brass, and Irons, and Kitchinware; Metals that we must use ou●… Medicine on: wherein the Brethren may have a penn'orth for ready money.

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: VVere the Orphans Parents sincere Professors?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: VVhy do you ask?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: Because we then are to deal justly, and give (in truth) their utmost value.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: 'Slid you'ld couzen else, and if their Parents were not of the faithfull? I will not trust you, now I think on't, till I ha' talk'd with your Pastor. Ha' you brought money to buy more Coals?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: No surely.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: No? how so?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p:
The Brethren bid me say unto you, Sir, Surely they, they will not venture any more till
they may see Projection.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: Y'have had for the instruments, as Bricks, and Lome, and Glasses, already, thirty pound; and for Materials, they say, some ninety more: and they have heard since, that one at Heidelberg made it of an Egg, and a small paper of Pin-dust.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: What's your name?

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: My name is Ananias.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Out, the Varlet that couzen'd the Apostles! Hence, away, flie Mischief. Had your holy Consistorie no name to send me of another sound, then wicked Ananias? Send your Elders hither to make atonement for you, quickly, and give me satisfaction, or out goes the fire, and down th'Alembecks, and the Fornace. Piger Henricus, or what not? Thou wretch, both Senicon and Bufo shall be lost, tell 'em. All hope of rooting out the Bishops, or th'Antichristian Hierarchie, shall perish, if they stay threescore minutes. The Aqueitie, Terreitie, and Sulphureitie, shall run together again, and all be anull'd, thou wicked Ananias.
This will fetch 'em, and make 'em haste toward their gulling more.
A man must deal like a rough Nurse, and fright those that are froward, to an appetite.

div.head: The SURPRISE.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: He prepares a Countrey-Interlude against the Iulian Feast, at the Presentment whereof, his foster-sister is stoln away, &c.

list.head: Number of Actors.
list.item: a Lord, who steals her away;
Iulio, in whose house the Scene is presented;
Orante, who marries the Foster-Sister, found to be Iulio's Daughter:
two Gentlemen, Friends, Philip the King, &c.

div.stage: Enter Iulio, and two or three Gentlemen, as to the Entertainment.

lg.l: COme, come, the Sports are coming on us;
Seat, seat your selves, Gentlemen.
Love is little, and therefore I present him:
Love is a fire, therefore you may lament him.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Alas poor Love, who are they that can quench him?

lg.l: Love shoots, therefore I bear his Bowe about:
And Love is blinde, therefore my eys are ou●….

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I never heard Love give reason for what he did, before.

lg.l: Let such as can see, see such as cannot: behold,
Our Goddesses all three strive for the Ball of Gold;
And here fair Paris comes, the hopeful youth of Troy,
Queen Hecubs darling-son, King Priams onely joy.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Is this Paris? I should have taken him for Hector rather.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Paris, at this time pray you hold your prating.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Paris can be angry, I see.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: At this time he comes as a Judge.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Mercy on all that looks upon him, say I.

lg.l: The thundering Seas whose watry fires
Washes the Whiting Mops.
The gentle Whale, whose feet so fell,
Flies o're the Mountain tops.
No roars so fierce, no throats so deep,
No howls can bring such fears
As Paris can, if Garden from
He calls his Dogs and Bears.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I, those they were that I fear'd all this while.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Yes, Jack-an-Apes.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir Paris.

lg.l: You may hold your peace, and stand farther out
o'th' way then: the lines will fall where they light.
Yes, Jack-an-Apes, he hath to sports,
And faces make like Mirth;
Whilst bellowing Bulls, the horned Beasts
Do toss from Ground to Earth.
Bloud Bear there is, as Cupid blind.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: That Bear would be whipt for loosing of his eys.

lg.l: Be whipped man may see,
But we present no such content, but Nymphs such as they be.

div.stage: Enter a Shepherd singing with three Nymphs, as Iuno, Pallas, Venus; Venus presented by his sister.

lg.l: Go Cupid blinde, conduct the dumb,
For Ladies must not speak here;
Let Shepherds sing with dancing feet,
And cords of Musick break here.
Now Ladies fight, with heels so light,
By lot your luck must fall,
Where Paris please, to do you ease,
And give the golden Ball.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Dance is ended; now to Judgment, Paris.

lg.l: Here, Iuno, here: but stay, I do espy
A pretty glance coming from Pallas eye:
Here, Pallas, here; yet stay again, methinks
I see the eye of Love, by Venus winks.
Oh close them both! Shut in those golden Eyne,
And I will kiss those sweet blind cheeks of thine.
Iuno is angry; yes, and Pallas frowns:
Would Paris now were gone from Ida's Downs.
They both are fair; but Venus has the Mole,
The fairest hair and sweetest dimple hole.
To her, or her, or her, or her, or neither;
Can one man please three Ladies altogether?
No, take it, Venus, toss it at thy pleasure,
Thou art the Lovers friend, beyond his measure.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Paris has done what Man can do, pleas'd me, who can do more?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Stay, here's another person.

lg.l: Come, lovely Venus, leave this lower Orb,
And mount with Mars up to his glorious sphear.

sp.speaker: Millers son.
sp.p: How now! what's he?

sp.speaker: Millers daughter.
sp.p: I'm ignorant what to do, Sir.

lg.l: Thy silver yoke of Doves are in the Team,
And thou shalt flie thorow Apollo's beam:
I'll see thee seated in thy golden Throne,
And hold with Mars a sweet Conjunction.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Ha! what fellow's this? he has carried away my sister Venus: he never rehears'd his part with me before.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: What follows now, Prince Paris?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Hue and cry: I think Sir, this is Venus voice, my own and onely sister.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: What, is there some Tragick-Act behind?

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: No, no, altogether Comical; Mars and Venus are in the old Conjunction, it seems.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis very improper then; for Venus never cries out when she Conjoyns with Mars.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: That's true indeed, they are out of their parts sure. It may be 'tis the Book-holders fault: I'll go see.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: How like you our Country-Revels, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Oh, they commend themselves, Sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: Methinks now Iuno and Minerva should take revenge on Paris: it cannot end without it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: It may follow; let's not premeditate the history.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: So, here's a Passion towards.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Help, help, if you be Gentlemen; my sister, my Venus is stoln away.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: The Story changes from our expectation.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Help, my father the Miller will hang me else: God Mars is a bawdy Villain; he said she should ride upon Doves: she's hors'd, she's hors'd whether she will or no.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Sure I think he's serious.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: She's hors'd upon a double Gelding, and a Stone-horse in the breech of her: the poor Wench cries help, and I crie help, and none of you will help.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Speak, is it the Shew, or dost thou bawl?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: A pox on the Ball; my sister bawls, and I bawl. Either bridle a horse and follow me, or give me a halter to hang my self: I cannot run so fast as a hog.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I'll fill the Country with pursuit, but I will find the Thief. My house thus abus'd?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: 'Tis my house that's abus'd, the sister of my flesh and blood: oh, oh, oh!

div.stage: Enter two Gentlemen with the Millers son.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: By all means discharge your follower.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: If we can gethim off. Sirrah, thou must needs run back.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: But I must not, unless you send a Bier, or a Licter at my back. I do not use to run from my friends.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Well, Go will serve turn: I have forgot.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: VVhat, Sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: See if I can think on't now.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I know what 'tis now.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: A Pistolet of that.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Done; you have forgot a device to send me away. You are going a smocking perhaps.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: His own, due, due i'faith Antonio: the Pistolet's his own.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I confess it, there 'tis.
Now if you could afford out of it a reasonable excuse to my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Yes, I can: but an excuse will not serve your turn: it must be a lie, a full lie, a downright lie, 'twill do no good else: if you'll go to the price of that.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Is a lie dearer then an excuse?

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Oh, treble: this is the price of an Excuse; but a Lie is two more. Look how many foils goes to a fair fall, so many Excuses go to a full Lie; and less cannot serve your turn, let any Taylor i'th' Town make it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis but reasonable; give him his price: let it be large enough now.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I'll warrant you cover him all over.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I would have proof of one now.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: VVhat? scale my Invention beforehand? you shall pardon me for that: VVell, I'll commend you to your Uncle, and tell him you'll be at home at Supper with him.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: By no means, I cannot come to night (man.)

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I know that too; you do not know a lie when you see it: remember it must stretch for all night.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I shall want stuff; I doubt 'twill come to the other Pistolet.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: VVell, lay out, you shall be no loser, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: It must be fac'd; you know there will be a yard of Dissimulation at least, (City-measure) and cut upon an untroth or two, lin'd with fables, that must needs be, cold weather coming; if it had a gallon of hypocrisie, 'twould do well; and hooked together with a couple of Conceits, that's necessitie: VVell, I'll bring in my Bill: I'll warrant you as fair a Lie, by that time I have done with it, as any Gentleman i'th' Town can swear too, if he would betray his Lord and Master.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: So, so, this necessary trouble's over.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I would you had bought an excuse of him before he went: you'll want one for your Lady.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p:
Oh Gentlemen, look to your selves, ye are
men of another world else; your enemies are upon you: the old house of the Bellides will fall upon your heads: Seignior Lisauro!

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Lisauro?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: And Don what call you him? he's a Gentleman: yet he has but a yeomans name, Don Tarse, Tarso, and a dozen at their heels.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Lisauro, Tarso, nor a dozen more, shall fright me from my ground, nor shun my path, let 'em come on in their ablest fury.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis worthily resolv'd: I'll stand by you, Sir; this way I am thy true friend.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I'll be gone, Sir, that one may live to tell what's become of you.— Put up, put up; will you never learn to know a Lie from an Aesops Fable? there's a taste for you now.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, adieu Trojan.

lg.l: My mind's unquiet; while Antonio
My Nephew is abroad, my heart is not at home,
Onely my fears stay with me; bad Companie;
But I cannot shift 'em off. This hatred
Betwixt the house o'th Bellides and Us,
Is not fair VVar: 'tis civil, but uncivil.
It has lasted too many Sun-sets.
Man should not lose so many days of Peace,
To satisfie the Anger of one minute.
I could repent it heartily. I sent
The Knave to attend my Antonio too,
Yet he returns no comfort to me neither.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: No, I must not.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Hah! he's come.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I must not; 'twill break his heart to hear it.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: How! he will not tell me for breaking of my heart: 'tis half split already, I must obscure and hear it.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I have spi'd him: Now to knock down a Don with a Lie, a silly harmless Lie; 'twill be valiantly done, and nobly perhaps.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I cannot hear him now.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Oh the bloody daies that we live in! the envious, malicious, deadly daies that we draw breath in!

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Now I hear too lowd.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: The children that ever shall be born, may rue it; for men that are slain now, might have liv'd to have got children, that might have curs'd their fathers.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Oh my posteritie is ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Oh sweet Antonio!

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Oh dear Antonio!

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Yet it was nobly done on both parts, when he and Lisauro met.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Oh, Death has parted'em.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: VVelcome my mortal Foe (saies one,) welcome my deadly Enemie (saies the other): off go their doublets, they in their shirts, and their swords, stark naked; here lies Antonio, here lies Lisauro: he comes upon him with an Embroccado, that he puts by with a puncta reversa: Lisauro recoils me two paces and some six inches back, takes his Career, and then, oh!

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Runs Antonio quite thorow.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Oh Villain!

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Quite thorow, between the arm and the body; so he had no hurt at that bout.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Goodness be prais'd.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p:
But then at th'next Encounter, he fetches me up Lisauro▪ Lisauro makes out a Long at him,
which he thinking to be a Passada, Antonio's foot sliping: down, oh, down.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Oh now thou art lost.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Oh but the quality of the thing: both Gentlemen, both Spanish Christians, yet one man to shed—

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Say his Enemies blood.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: His hair may come by divers Casualties, though he never go into the Field with his Foe: but a man to lose nine ounces and two drams of blood at one wound, thirteen and a scruple at another, and to live till he die in cold blood: yet the Chirurgeon (that cur'd him) said, if Pia-mater had not been perished, he had been a lives man to this day.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: There he concludes he is gone.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: But all this is nothing: now I come to the point.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I, the point, that's deadly: the ancient blow over the buckler ne'r went half so deep.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Yet Pity bids me keep in my Charity: for me to pull an old Mans ears from his head with telling of a Tale: Oh foul Tale! Furthermore, there is the charge of Burial; every one will cry blacks, blacks, that had but the least finger in his blood, though ten degrees removed when 'twas done. Moreover, the Chirurgeon (that made an end of him) will be paid: Sugar-plums, and Sweet-breads; yet it may be the Man may recover again, and die in his bed.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: VVhat motley stuff is this? Sirrah, speak truth what hath befall'n my dear Antonio; what thou keep'it back from truth, thou shalt speak in pain: do not look to finde a Limb in his right place, a Bone unbroke, nor so much flesh unbroil'd of all that Mountain, as a VVorm might sup on; dispatch, or be dispatch'd.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Alas Sir, I know nothing, but that Antonio is a man of Gods making to this hour; 'tis not two since I left him so.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: When didst thou leave him?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: In the same clothes he had on when he went from you.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Does he live?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I saw him drink.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Is he wounded?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: He may have a cut in the leg by this time: for Don Martin and he were at whole slashes.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Met he not with Lysauro?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I do not know her.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Her? Lysauro is a man as he is.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I saw ne'r a man like him.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Didst not thou discourse a fight betwixt Antonio and Lysauro?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: I, to my self: I hope a man may give himself the Lie, if it please him?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Didst thou lie then?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: As sure as you live now.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I live the happier by it: when will he return?

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: That he sent me to tell you, within these ten days, at farthest.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Ten days? he was not wont to be absent two.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Nor I think he will not.
He said he would be at home to morrow; but I love to speak within my compass.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: You shall speak within mine, Sir, now. Within there: take this fellow into custody:
keep him safe, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: Safe! do you hear? take notice what plight you finde me in: if there want but a Collop, or a Steak o'me, look to't.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: If my Nephew return not in his health to morrow, thou goest to the Rack.

lg.l: Let me go to th'manger first;
I had rather eat Oats then Hay.

div.stage: Enter Philip, Orante, Miller, Julio, Millers son, severally.

sp.speaker: Mill. son.
sp.p: So-hoh, Miller, Miller,
Look out, Miller: Is there ne'r a Miller amongst you here, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Miller.
sp.p: Yes, here is a Miller amongst Gentlemen, a Gentleman-Miller.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I should not be far off then; there went but a pair of Shears and a Bodkin between us. Will you to work, Miller? here's a Maid has a Sack full of News for you: Shall your Stones walk? will you grinde, Miller?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: This your son, Franio?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: My ungratious, my disobedient, my unnatural, my Rebel-son, (my Lord.)

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Fie, your hopper runs over, Miller.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: This Villain (of my own flesh and blood) was accessary to the stealing of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Oh Mountain!
Shalt thou call a Mole-hill a scab upon the face of the earth? though a Man be a Thief, shall a Miller call him so? Oh egregious!

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Remember, sirrah, who you speak before.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I speak before a Miller, a Thief in grain; for he steals Corn. He that steals a Wench, is a true Man, to him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Can you prove that?

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I'll prove it strongly.
He that steals Corn, steals the Bread of the Common-wealth: he that steals a Wench, steals but the flesh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And how is their Bread-stealing more criminal then the flesh?

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
He that steals bread, steals that which is lawful every day: he that steals flesh, steals nothing from the
fasting day: Ergo, to steal the bread is the arranter Thief.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: This is to some purpose.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Again, he that steals flesh, steals for his own belly full: he that steals bread, robs the Guts of others: Ergo, the arranter Thief the Bread-stealer. Again, he that steals flesh, steals once and gives over; yes, and often pays for it; the other steals every day without satisfaction. To conclude, Bread-stealing is the more Capital Crime: for what he steals, he puts it in at the head; he that steals flesh (as the Dutch Author saies) puts it in at the foot (the lower Member.) VVill you go as you are now, Miller?

lg.l: I can no longer own
What is not mine with a free Conscience.
My Liege, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For what? who knows this woman?

sp.speaker: Miller.
sp.p: I, best (my Lord.)
I have been acquainted with her these forty Summers, and as many Winters, were it Spring agen; she's like the Gout, I—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh, your wife.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: 'Tis oh my wife indeed (my Lord) a painful stitch to my side; would it were pickt out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well, Sir, your silence.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: VVill you be older and older every day then other? the longer you live, the older still? Must his Majestie command your silence, ere you'll hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your reprehension runs into the same fault: Pray Sir, will you be silent.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I have told him this before now (my Liege) but Age will have his course, and his weaknesses.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Good Sir, your forbearance.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: And his frailties, and his follies (as I may say) that cannot hold his tongue ere he be bidden.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why sirrah, ha?

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: But I believe your Majestie will not be long troubled with him: I hope that woman has something to confess, will hang 'em both.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sirrah, you'll pull your Destinie upon you, If you cease not the sooner.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Nay, I have done; yet it grieves me that I should call that man father, that should be so shameless, that being commanded to hold his tongue—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: To th'Porters Lodge with him.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I thank your Grace, I have a friend there.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: It hardly will get passage, it is a sorrow of that greatness grown, 'less it dissolve in tears, and come by parcels.

sp.speaker: Millers wife.
sp.p: I'll help you, Sir, in the delivery, and bring you forth a joy: you lost a daughter.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: 'Twas that recounted thought brought forth these sorrows.

sp.speaker: Mill. wife.
sp.p: She's found again; Know you this Mantle, Sir?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Mill. wife
sp.p: This did enwrap your child, now the Counts wife, &c.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Oh thou hast ta'n so many years from me, and made me young as was her birth-day to me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You knew this before.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Oh, oh; Item for you Miller.

sp.speaker: Miller.
sp.p: I did, my Liege, I must confess I did; We poor ones love, and would have comfort, Sir, as well as great.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
I beseech you, (my Liege) let this Woman be a little farther examin'd; let the words of her Conscience be search'd. I would know how she came by me; I am a
lost child, if I be theirs: though I have been brought up in a Mill, yet I had ever a minde (methought) to be a greater man.

sp.speaker: Mill. Wife.
sp.p: Thou art mine own flesh and blood, born of mine own body.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: 'Tis very unlikely that such a body should bear me; there's no trust in these Millers. Woman, tell the truth, my father shall forgive thee, whatsoever he was; were he Knight, Esquire, or Captain; less he could not be.

sp.speaker: Mill. Wife.
sp.p: Thou art mine own child, Boy.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: And was the Miller my father?

sp.speaker: Mill. Wife.
sp.p: Wouldst thou make thy mother a whore, Knave?

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I, if she make me a Bastard. The Rack must make her confess, I shall never come to know who I am else. I have a worshipful mind in me sure: methinks I do scorn poor folks.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: You both shall be rewarded bountifully. We'll be a kin too, Brother and Sister shall be chang'd with us ever.

div.stage: To the Miller and his wife.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Thank you (Uncle) my Sister is my Cousin yet at the last cast: farewell Sister-foster. If I had known the Civil Law would have allowed it, thou hadst had another manner of husband then thou hast: but much good do thee; I'll dance at thy Wedding, kiss the Bride, and so.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Why how now, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mill. Son.
sp.p: 'Tis lawful now, she's none of my sister.

lg.l: It was a Miller and a Lord
That had a Scabbard and a Sword,
He put it up in the Country word,
The Miller and his Daughter.
She has a face, and she can sing,
She has a grace, and she can spring;
She has a place, with another thing,
Tradoodle.

sp.p: I would I were acquainted with your Taylor (noble Brother.)

sp.speaker: Orante.
sp.p: You may, there he is.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: If you have any work for me, I can fit you. Sir, I fitted the Lady.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: My sister (Taylor)? VVhat fits her, will hardly fit me: you have a true Yard (Taylor)?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Ne'r a whit too long, I warrant you.

lg.l: Then (Taylor) march with me away;
I scorn these Robes, I must be gay,
My Noble Brother he shall pay
Tom Taylor.

div.head: The DOCTORS of Dull-head Colledge.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: A Love-sick Gentleman, by the over-curious care of his kindred, is perplexed with unnecessary Physitians, who are by some of his merry Visitants and Companions baffled, and he released from their vexation.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: A Pleurisie, I see it.

sp.speaker: 2 Ph.
sp.p: I rather hold for tremor cordis.

sp.speaker: 3 Ph.
sp.p: Do you mark the Foeces?

sp.speaker: 2 Ph.
sp.p: 'Tis a most pestilent contagious Feaver, a Surfet, a plaguy Surfet: he must bleed.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: 3 Ph.
sp.p: I say, bleed.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: I say 'tis dangerous, the person being spent so much beforehand, and nature drawn so low: Clysters, cool Clysters.

sp.speaker: 2 Ph.
sp.p: Now, with your favour, I should think a Vomit; for take away the Cause, the Effect must follow: the stomack's foul and fur'd, the pot's inflam'd yet.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Will it please you draw near? the sick Gentleman grows worse and worse still.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: We will attend him.

sp.speaker: 2 Ph.
sp.p: He shall do well, my friend.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Masters love, Sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Ph.
sp.p: There's no doubt in him, none at all, never fear him.

div.stage: Enter Frank sick, Physitians, an Apothecary.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: Clap on the Cataplasm.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen, good learned Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 Ph.
sp.p: And see those broths there ready within this hour: pray keep your arms in; the air is raw, and ministers much evil.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Pray leave me, I beseech you leave me, Gentlemen, I have no other sickness but your presence; convey your Cataplasms to those that need 'em, your Vomits and your Clysters.

sp.speaker: 3 Ph.
sp.p: Pray be rul'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: Bring in the Lettice Cap; you must be shav'd, Sir, and then how suddenly we'll make you sleep!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Till Dooms-day: What unnecessary nothings are these about a wounded mind?

sp.speaker: 2 Ph.
sp.p: How do ye?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: VVhat questions they propound too! How do you, Sir? I am glad to see you well.

sp.speaker: 3 Ph.
sp.p: A great distemper, it grows hotter still.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: Open your mouth, I pray, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Can you tell me how old I am then? there's my hand, pray shew me how many broken shins within this two year. VVho would be thus in fetters? Good Master Doctor, and you dear Doctor, and the third sweet Doctor, and as pretious Master Apothecary, I do pray you to give me leave to live a little longer: ye stand before me like my blacks.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: How dost thou Frank? bear up, boy; what, shrink i'th' sinews for a little sickness?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Thou art a mad Companion, never staid, Tom?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: Let Rogues be staid, that have no habitation, a Gentleman may wander: sit thee down, Frank, and see what I have brought thee: Come, discover, open the Scene, and let the work appear: a friend at need, you Rogue, is worth a Million.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: VVhat hast thou there, a Julip?

sp.speaker: Hylas.
sp.p: He must not touch it, 'tis present death.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ye are an▪ Ass, a Twir-pipe, a Jeffery-John-bopeep: thou minister? thou mend a left-handed pack-saddle; out Puppy. My friend Frank, but a very foolish fellow: dost thou see that bottle? view it well.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I do, Tom.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: There be as many lives in't as a Cat carries, 'tis everlasting liquor.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: VVhat?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: Old Sack, boy, old reverend Sack.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I see no harm, Tom, drink with moderation.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Drink't with Sugar, which I have ready here; and here's a glass, boy, fill it: hang up your Julips, and your Portugal-possets, your Barley-broths, and Sorrel sops; they are mangy, and breed the Scratches onely: give me Sack: have at thee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Do: I'll pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Take it off thrice, and then cry, Heigh! like a Huntsman, with a clear heart, and no more fits I'll warrant thee; the onely Cordial, Frank.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: Are the things ready?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Long since, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: Bring out the oyls then.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Now or never, Gentlemen, do me a kindness, and deliver me.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: From whom, boy?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: From those things that talk there, Physitians, Tom, Physitians, Scouring-sticks; they mean to read upon me.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: And be thou confident we will deliver thee: for look ye, Doctors, say the Devil were sick now, his horns saw'd off, and his head bound with a biggin, sick of a Calenture, taken by a surfet of stinking souls, at his Nephews and S. Dunstans, what would you minister upon the sudden? your Judgement, short and sound.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.p: A fools head.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: No Sir, it must be a Physitians, for three causes; the first, because it is a bald-head likely, which will down easily without apple-pap.

sp.speaker: 3 Ph.
sp.p: A main cause.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: So it is, and well considered. The second, for 'tis fill'd with broken Greek, Sir, which so tumbles in his stomach, Doctor, and works upon the Crudities, conceive me, the fears and the fiddle-strings within it, that those damned souls must disembogue again.

sp.speaker: Hylas.
sp.p: Or meeting with the Stygian humour.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hylas.
sp.p: Forc'd with a Cataplasm of Crackers.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: Ever.

sp.speaker: Hylas.
sp.p: Scowre all before him like a Scavinger.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: Satisfecisti Domine. My last cause, my last is, and not least, most learned Doctors, because in most Physitians heads (I mean those that are most excellent, and old withall, and angry, though a Patient say his prayers, and Paracelsians that do trade with poisons, we have it by tradition of great VVriters) there is a kinde of Toadstone bred, whose vertue the Doctor, being dry'd.

sp.speaker: I Ph.
sp.p: VVe are abus'd, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I take it so, or shall be: for say, the Belly-ach caused by an inundation of Pease-porridge, are we therefore to open the Port-vein, or the Port-Esquiline?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A learned question: or grant the Diaphragma by a rupture, the Sign being then in the head of Capricorn—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: Meet with the passion Hypercondriaca, and so cause a Carnositie in the Kidneys, must not the brains being butter'd with this humour? answer me that.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Most excellently argued.

sp.speaker: 2 Ph.
sp.p: The next fit you will have, my most fine Scholer, Bedlam shall finde a salve for. Fare you well, Sir: we came to do you good, but these young Doctors, it seems, have boar'd our Noses.

sp.speaker: 3 Ph.
sp.p: Drink hard, Gentlemen, and get unwholsom Drabs; 'tis ten to one then we shall hear farther from ye, your Note alter'd.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: And wilt thou be gone, says one.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: And wilt thou be gone, says tother.

lg.l: Then take, take the odd Crown,
To mend thy old Gown,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And we'll be gone all together.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: My learned Tom, gramercy.

And as you like, he'll furnish you with more.
